TALK.START.PARA: —As a courtesy, I inform the House that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, will be absent from Question Time today on official business. Any questions normally addressed to him should be directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that the three Sydney Smith Family centres have recorded an average of 250 people a day visiting for food, and 100 for clothing, that there has been a 16 per cent increase in people asking for assistance from the Smith Family and that half of the 100,000 people who asked for help in 1986-87 were children? How does the Government hope to achieve its target of having `no children living in poverty in 1990' if it continues to restrict the capacity of non-government organisations to help the poor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is rather rich, coming as it does from an Opposition which, when in government, was responsible for creating mass unemployment.
—That is not so.

—Honourable members opposite can respond like that, but if they were administering social security in 1982 and had to cope with an additional 300,000 beneficiaries in one year, many of whom had dependent children, and if in subsequent years they had to deal with the situation in which the real value--
—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. The question is about the problems of people today. The Minister is giving us a yesterday answer. These people are suffering.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the Minister.

—I understand why the Opposition would want to rewrite history. The rate of unemployment grew to over 10 per cent of the work force; there was a doubling of unemployment in the last year of the previous Government. There was a massive increase in child poverty. The number of children of pensioner and beneficiary families in poverty grew from 330,000, which it was when we left office in 1975, to over 800,000 during the period of the previous Government. What did that mean for the Smith Family? It meant that a burden was placed on that agency and on other voluntary agencies.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government's record in the area of income security stands high. We have lifted the level of pensions from 22.8 per cent to almost 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We have increased payments for pensioner and beneficiary children from $10 to $17 a week. This amount is about to be increased to $22. This Government has introduced-no government has done this before-an age-related allowance of an additional $6 or $28 for older children. Since we have been in government we have doubled the mother's-guardian's allowance from $6 to $12. We have not only increased rent assistance from $10 to $15 but also for the first time we have extended rent assistance for low income working families.

For low income people with children at school, we have increased the payment for 16- and 17-year-old young people at school from something like $22 to $40, thus helping to achieve school retention rates where it is most crucial. From 1 January next year the amount will be increased to $50.

Of course there is always concern that governments should do more for those most disadvantaged people within the Australian community. This Government has a record of creating nearly 900,000 jobs on the one hand and on the other hand of providing increased, additional and more targeted assistance for low income people. This has been done in spite of the economic constraints. The coalition Government ran away from office leaving a deficit for this Treasurer to manage of nearly $10 billion. This Government has not only made those social achievements but also balanced the books while it has been doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can he explain how the new earnings credit system will assist pensioners who take a temporary job as Father Christmas over the festive season?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the question clearly has a lighthearted tone, particularly as the Parliament moves towards the festive season, the fact that the Government has introduced the earnings credit scheme is, of course, very good news for people with part time or casual earnings. During the election campaign the Government promised a new earnings credit scheme to help pensioners beat poverty traps by giving them room to increase their income and Father Christmases across Australia will be among the first to benefit.

ANSWER.PARA: The new arrangements mean that from 1 November they can earn up to $1,000 each from casual jobs without having their pension reduced or losing their fringe benefits. The typical Father Christmas may earn, say, $250 a week for four weeks during December. For some such people that will be their only annual income over and above the pension. Under the ordinary income test such a person would have his pension reduced by $105 a week and lose the pensioner health benefit card during that period. Clearly, that person has been discriminated against compared with the pensioner who earned $1,000 evenly over the year and maintained entitlement to full pension and fringe benefits.

Under the new arrangement a single pensioner can save up earnings credits from weeks when he or she earns less than the $40 per week allowed as the free area. This initiative means that pensioners can accept full time jobs at some time during the year without having to worry about losing their pension, at least until their credit is exhausted. So Father Christmas will be able to work and to keep the full pension and the pensioner health benefit card.

There has been some confusion between the earnings credit and the free income limit. Basically, if pensioners do not use up all of the free area, they can roll over the difference to increase the free area applying to future earnings. From now on we are giving pensioners $1,000 earning credit so anyone who has not used all of his free area since 1 January can earn up to $1,000 this Christmas and retain the full pension.

In conclusion, I remind the House, particularly in view of the previous question, that in the last six months, despite the fiscal restraint and balancing the books, we introduced poverty trap measures from 1 July to increase the general amounts that pensioners can earn every week. By Christmas we will have increased pensions and we will have made it easier for pensioners to work without worrying about losing their pension or full benefits. Taking the pension increases, the earnings credit scheme and, indeed, the family assistance package, this Christmas will be a much happier Christmas for tens of thousands of Australian pensioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to a report in the Australian newspaper of 21 November indicating that Treasury officials have confirmed that key Budget forecasts for the economy have been revised in the wake of the crash. In view of the revised outlook for world economic growth, I ask the Treasurer whether the projected current account deficit of $11.5 billion for 1987-88 has been revised. If so, by how much? I further ask him: In light of the latest revision of key Budget forecasts, how can the Government's strategy for 1987-88 still be on track?

—The Treasury from time to time during the year does a forecasting round. We will be doing it again soon and often that does vary some of the forecasts which are laid down at Budget time. This in no way, of course, invalidates the general thrust of the strategy, so the last point in the question does not have much weight to it. The latest round of the joint economic forecasting group has not taken place, but the information which will be dealt with is in the possession of the Government. We make some of this information available as we see fit from time to time. Sometimes I do this in speeches to the Economic Planning Advisory Council but, frankly, this just depends upon some of the variables and whether in fact we think the debate is advanced by its release.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASSETS TEST AND FRINGE BENEFITS TAX

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the estimated savings generated by the assets test and the revenue collected by the fringe benefits tax (FBT)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Chifley for his question. I can inform him that the estimated savings from the assets test for 1987-88 are $160m. The amount is expected to grow to $300m by 1989-90. Madam Speaker-I am sorry, I should say Mr Acting Speaker; I am still recovering from the fishing. I note that yesterday the shadow Treasurer, who unfortunately seems to gave gone-no, there he is; come here, Andrew; cop it like a man-expressed, as it is quoted, a `firm view' that the assets test on pensions would go under a hypothetical Liberal government. In these circumstances, one has to wonder whether the shadow Treasurer has cleared his comments with the Federal President of the Liberal Party of Australia, who, as we know, is a well known supporter of the assets test. I simply remind honourable members of the very firm statement made by Mr Elliott, quoted in the Courier-Mail of 21 May this year. He was quoted at a Courier-Mail business dinner as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition by some sections of the Liberal Party to means testing welfare payments was `disgraceful' and `welfare' payments should be based on need-not on right'.

That clear statement by the Federal President of the Liberal Party attacking statements like those of the shadow Treasurer is firmly in line with the Government's approach to welfare payment. That is the underlying rationale behind the assets test which the shadow Treasurer now says he has a firm view to abolish.

In regard to that part of the honourable member's question which asked about the fringe benefits tax, I can inform him that the fringe benefits tax is collecting around $750m a year and, together with substantiation requirements, it collects over $1 billion. Again with this matter we find another area of disagreement in the Opposition. I look at this morning's Australian Financial Review and I see the heading `Opposition softens on lucrative FBT in wake of crash'. Here we see the shadow Treasurer saying:
We'll have to review the economic circumstances that we inherit, but we're not prepared to go back to the situation where rorts continue.

In other words, the shadow Treasurer is now reported as softening on the fringe benefits tax. I ask honourable members to contrast that with the publicly stated position of the Leader of the Opposition. His statement is, `We'll throw it out lock, stock and barrel'. In regard to the fringe benefits tax he said on 7 October 1986:
The principle of it is wrong and so is the administration.

Here we have the shadow Treasurer and the Federal President of the Liberal Party in direct contradiction with one another and we have the shadow Treasurer and the Leader of the Opposition in absolute contrast. It is interesting in those circumstances that we have the Leader of the Opposition saying on radio this morning:
There is no way on earth any political party can ask the public to support it if it presents the impression of division at the top.

What greater impression of division at the top can we have than this division between the shadow Treasurer, the Federal President of the Liberal Party and the Leader of the Opposition. They are hopeless.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. It concerns World Heritage listing of the rainforests of north Queensland. Since the High Court of Australia might have to determine the conservation status of areas to be protected if Queensland challenges the World Heritage values of its rainforests and also determine whether the Commonwealth is making a de facto acquisition of State land, will the Prime Minister establish an inquiry similar to the Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests as a more appropriate way of examining Queensland rainforests for World Heritage values to determine whether some logging can continue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the honourable member that there can be no real doubt that the wet tropics of north-east Queensland are of World Heritage status. I do not think there is any doubt about that at all. The environmental values of the area have been well researched and well documented, such that there is no real point in holding an inquiry similar to the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests inquiry. We are convinced on this side of the House that logging is incompatible with protection of the environmental values of the wet tropics of north-east Queensland. It is interesting that there is reference in this respect to a High Court challenge. I remind him that his Queensland National Party Leader for the time being, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, made it clear recently that there was little chance of any challenge against World Heritage listing succeeding and, therefore, has cast serious doubt on whether Queensland would proceed in any way with such a challenge.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said on 5 June when announcing the Government's intention to proceed towards nominating rainforests for World Heritage listing, we had no choice in the circumstances but to proceed with this action. The Queensland Government refused to agree to stop logging of the rainforests. I point out to the honourable gentleman that the official Opposition environmental spokesman, Senator Puplick, has left no doubt at all as far as he is concerned as to where he stands on the issue. He said in his Press statement of 24 August this year under the heading `Queensland Wet Tropical Rainforests':

I have expressed the belief that the Queensland wet tropical forests are worthy of inclusion on the World Heritage List: they are unique; they are of international significance; they contain one of the greatest and scientifically most significant concentrations of unique flora and fauna in the world.
The Opposition spokesman said:
Australia is the only industrialised country with remaining tropical rainforests and we have a responsibility to protect them.

The Opposition spokesman said that on this issue. But, more significantly, even from the point of view of the honourable member, his own parliamentary Leader has refused to oppose World Heritage listing in principle, saying that he wanted at least some of the area protected and enhanced. I repeat to the honourable member that assistance will be provided to help create alternative employment opportunities in activities such as tourism and park and plantation management. I can assure him that no final decisions will be made on the nature or the level of assistance until consultations are completed.

You, Mr Acting Speaker, will appreciate, and so will the honourable gentleman, that we accepted public submissions. They were received until 22 October. Therefore, I trust that the exposition of the position of the Opposition as a whole, the very qualified position of the honourable member's own Leader in this place and the refusal of his leader in Queensland to take any challenge to the High Court of Australia, will set this matter in appropriate perspective for the honourable gentleman.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is the Minister aware of a proposal to allocate a floor of the Royal Darwin Hospital to a private organisation known as Health and Life Care to operate as a private hospital? Can the Minister advise what impact this could have on the availability of Medicare services in the Northern Territory to those people without private insurance? Can the Minister also advise the House whether this proposal has the potential to impact on the contribution rates for those people with private insurance? Can the Minister say whether he will be seeking assurances from the Northern Territory Government that this proposal will not disadvantage Territorians irrespective of whether they have private insurance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the rather unusual decision of the Northern Territory Government to turn over one whole floor of its public hospital to a private company to make of it a private hospital. I understand that the loss of those 72 beds has already caused considerable disorganisation in the hospital and concerns to obstetric patients by, for instance, the reduction of beds and often the putting together of rather inappropriate wards.

ANSWER.PARA: This issue raises a number of major policy issues which I believe it would have been appropriate for the Northern Territory Government to have discussed with this Government. It raises the problem as to whether, as a result of giving away this whole floor, the Northern Territory Government can continue to guarantee unrestricted access to free public hospital treatment for uninsured people. There is also the question of whether an agreement has been made between the Northern Territory Government and the operators of the proposed private hospital to redirect all privately insured patients from the public hospital to the private beds. It is important that we get an answer to that.

Whilst some of the newspapers in the Northern Territory have been pretending that Territorians were disadvantaged by not having this provision, people in the Northern Territory should understand the full implications of this proposal. Currently, Northern Territory people can get access to the Darwin Hospital and be treated as private patients at a cost of $120 a day for accommodation. Under the private hospital proposal, accommodation fees will rise to as high as $360 a day. That will certainly not benefit most Territorians with private health insurance. Indeed, it will mean a significant rise in private health insurance rates in the Territory. Moreover, a serious social problem arises if one decides within a public hospital to have a special floor set aside as a private hospital in that one may well develop special first class treatment for that one floor compared with the rest, so the result in the future will be that people in the public hospital-the poor, the Aborigines and others-will get second class treatment while those insured will get first class treatment on a special floor.

Again I say, given the major policy implications of this decision, that I am surprised that the Northern Territory Health Minister has not approached me directly to discuss some of these major issues. I believe that Minister should initiate discussions immediately so that this Government can receive proper assurances about those aspects of the proposal. Moreover, one might ask, as a private hospital is to be built in Darwin within the next 12 to 18 months and within the hospital grounds, why it is necessary for the Northern Territory to cause all of this disruption to give over this floor of the hospital to a private firm. Finally, if the Northern Territory Government believes that it can simply authorise more private hospital beds, and systematically close down its public hospital sector in this way, it should understand that the Commonwealth will have to review the level of grants currently payable.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: POSITION OF AUSTRALIAN CONSUL-GENERAL IN NEW YORK

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will the Minister confirm that the Labor member for Adelaide recently flew to New York for the purpose of checking out the Australian Consul-General's facilities as a prerequisite to his acceptance of that position? Could the Minister inform the House whether Mr Hurford found the role sufficiently attractive for him to accept the position of Consul-General? Has the Minister spoken to the honourable member for Robertson, Mr Cohen, about his future?

—I have no idea whether Mr Hurford has travelled to New York, and I have no idea about the reference made by the honourable member to the honourable member for Robertson. In relation to any appointments that this Government may make in the future, I have no doubt that those opposite will follow those appointments with interest and in due course will ascertain who has been appointed to where.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of claims that the Government's child support scheme could result in hardship for sole parents? Is there any truth in the claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I am aware of the claim made by the honourable member for Bradfield, the shadow Minister, that the Government's scheme could cause hardship to sole parents. He claimed that a harsh assets test will apply, and will include the family home. This is simply not true. The Government's scheme links the family law and the social security systems. It is essential in this area that sole parents not be unnecessarily worried. Where maintenance is provided by way of capital or lump sum that maintenance will be income tested, just like with current cash maintenance.

ANSWER.PARA: The Family Law Amendment Bill, which has been passed by the House, requires specification in the family law system of capital or lump sum maintenance as maintenance. Only when a capital or lump sum amount is identified in the court system as maintenance will it be income tested in the social security system. This is a fair and equitable way to treat maintenance. All maintenance, regardless of form, will attract the income test. The honourable member for Bradfield called on the Government to respond to the criticism of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) that the child support scheme will put many supporting parents into poverty. Of course ACOSS has never made such criticism. It has complained that the scheme will not do enough to lift those who do not receive maintenance out of poverty.

I think it is important that the House know that when the child support scheme is introduced it will not lead to any sole parent being worse off. It will represent a significant attack upon the work disincentive for sole parents. Under the current arrangements a sole parent with two children, receiving $30 in maintenance for each child and earning $100 a week part time, could lose $48 a week because of that earned income. Under the new separate income test, that same pensioner will lose only $18 because of the earned income. This will turn maintenance into real income support to be received regularly, on time, each month. At the moment maintenance is an extra amount which is received sporadically, with no security for those who are lucky enough to receive it. The scheme will more than double the number of pensioners receiving maintenance, and all of those who get maintenance for the first time because of the scheme will be better off.

The separate income test on maintenance strikes a fair balance between the interests of the taxpayers and the interests of the custodial parent. The custodial parent will get maintenance in the free area of $15 for one child plus $5 for each additional child. For maintenance above these free areas, pensions will be reduced by 50c in the dollar, as is the case in other social security income tests. In conclusion, it is important that people look at the whole of the Government's policies with respect to sole parents. If they do, they will see all those policies together as being the most significant attack on the poverty of sole parents, certainly in the time since changes to the Family Law Act in the 1970s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs called for a report on allegations that a former Queensland member of the Legislative Assembly, Mr Jack Aiken, has been running an immigration scheme based on claims of special influence, offers of arranged marriages, employer nomination for non-existent jobs and investment in business ventures in which Mr Aiken was a partner? If so, will the Minister inform the House of the outcome of his investigation? What action will the Minister take with respect to those immigration applications which would not have been approved had it not been for Mr Aiken's efforts to artificially structure them to fit Australia's immigration requirements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. It is true that certain allegations were raised in the Press. Prior to those allegations, information was given to the Department which was then handed on to the Australian Federal Police for further investigation. I do not have the follow-up to its investigations on this matter. The honourable member raised questions which have been of some concern to me since I have had this portfolio. We have gone about the business migration program in a totally unregulated manner. As the honourable member undoubtedly knows, I have now tried to give that some sort of structure because a number of members of parliament have found it appropriate to go into this business after they have left the various State and Federal chambers. Not only those ex-members of parliament but also hundreds and hundreds of others set themselves up as experts on business migration to this country. We have seen a rapid increase in the number of applicants in this area. I think that what I have announced in terms of business migration will be of benefit both in the quality and quantity of the business people that will be migrating to Australia. The question that the honourable member raises about whether people are dealing with these matters appropriately is very serious. It has been taken seriously. If I get any other information which I can make available to the House, I will certainly do so.

—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training advise the House what steps the Government has taken to increase the opportunities for girls in high schools to study mathematics and science subjects? Would these steps increase the likelihood of girls studying science at tertiary level? Given our shortage of scientists and engineers, does the Government place a high priority on such a program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for St George for his question.
—Give them something on accountancy, too.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—The retention rates of girls in high schools to year 12 exceed those of boys. Indeed, the participation rate of girls and women, particularly in the age group 17 to 19 years, in tertiary education substantially exceeds that of males in the same age group. The important fact is, however, that there is a high concentration of female enrolments in tertiary education in the humanities, the arts and teacher education, and a very low participation rate in science, the applied sciences, engineering and so on. One reason seems to be that girls take decisions early in their secondary education not to continue with maths and sciences, thereby limiting their options for tertiary education study and denying the country a great pool of talent represented by girls and young women in the great technological challenges that face us.

ANSWER.PARA: The solution to the problem is not simple. Insofar as it relates to difficulties in curriculum, the Government in the Budget announced a $1m project to conduct an exercise to see whether the curriculum might be improved in higher secondary school to encourage girls to continue study of these subjects. The matter is even more complex than that. It goes to the attitudes of teachers, parents and employers. This is a joint responsibility for everybody to try to encourage girls in particular, but also boys, to continue with maths and sciences in secondary school to ensure that more students are able to continue tertiary education in these vital subjects. This is a particular responsibility of employers. Young people in deciding what courses to undertake at university and college are keenly aware of where employment opportunities are to be found. If employers were to show a greater preparedness to employ graduates in sciences, engineering and other subjects, I think that we would see a quick response from young people in taking such courses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports in the Queensland media that Queensland businesses are paying more than $1m a year extra because poor Telecom account checking procedures resulted in overcharging, that telephone accounts in almost 60 per cent of cases were found to be inaccurate, that 60 per cent of Telecom business subscribers whose bills were inaccurate were found to have been overcharged, and the claim that, if this error rate is projected across Australia, nothing short of a national scandal exists? If the Minister's attention has been drawn to those reports, has he taken up the matter with Telecom and, if so, to what effect? If not, will the Minister urgently take up the matter with Telecom?
—I am not aware of the details of that matter. I shall obtain details for the honourable member and bring them back to the House in due course.
—My question is to the Attorney-General. What is the Government's attitude in regard to calls by the business community for legislative changes to allow companies to buy back their own shares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the last Ministerial Council meeting in September a report was received from the Companies and Securities Law Reform Committee. It had had this matter under deliberation for two years or more, and the Ministerial Council decided that it would deal with it at its next meeting, which is in December. I mention that because there has been some Press comment that the matter was before the Federal Parliament and has been delayed. In fact, it has not even reached that position.

ANSWER.PARA: The merits of the proposal are that it would give companies opportunities to buy their own shares, a facility which at present is not available. That process would lead to shares being deemed to be more valuable, and it is thought that in the present climate that might be a satisfactory result. There are problems involved in the proposal, as the report mentions that the offer should be on a selective basis. One can see the difficulties that would be created if only certain shareholders were to be given the opportunity of selling their shares at above share market value. It would also affect creditors to the extent that the amount of money available for them would not be as great as if the money had been used in the utilisation of the purchase of the shares. Further, there is the fact that perhaps the directors might want to give themselves some insurance against any takeover offer. Thus, there are pros and cons.

The Committee recommended that the articles of association be amended to provide that, if that were to be the provision, it would be reviewed every three years and would also require a special resolution. In other words, there are factors of some interest and it may well be that the scheme could be given some consideration. The real issue at the moment is what is in the best interests of the company and the shareholders. From a national point of view, we would be most anxious that companies would be more interested in expanding their production and increasing their productivity by utilising their capital, rather than merely insuring themselves against a takeover bid.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Community Services and Health. By way of background, I refer the Minister to an answer he gave to a question in this House on 3 November concerning remarks made by the Victorian Premier. The Minister replied that the Premier was incorrect in his criticism of the Federal Government because the level of private health insurance in Australia had remained static for the past 12 to 18 months. Is the Minister aware that figures released by his own Department and, according to his Department, approved by him before release, show that in Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania the level of private health insurance as a percentage of the population is at historically low levels? In Victoria it is the lowest for three years and only in New South Wales, where there has been prolonged industrial disruption, is it marginally higher. How does the Minister reconcile his own Department's figures with his statement to the House on 3 November? Does he now concede that the Victorian Premier is correct when he states that the Federal Government's health policies are `illogical and distort incentives'?

—As I remember, I said on that date that the figures had remained relatively static over the past 18 months. If the honourable member examines the increase that has taken place in New South Wales, together with the marginal falls that have taken place in the other States, I think he will find that that is basically a correct statement. It is true, particularly in the past three months, that in all States except New South Wales there seems to have been a somewhat greater fall-off in the rate of private health insurance. But across the whole nation the figures have been relatively static during that 18-month period.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE USE AND EFFECTS OF CHEMICAL AGENTS ON AUSTRALIAN PERSONNEL IN VIETNAM

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs been drawn to an article which recently appeared in the Adelaide News stating that a particular Vietnam veteran would have to travel to Canberra at great personal expense to read the transcript of evidence given to the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam? If so, is it a fact that the veteran mentioned in the article would have to pay up to $9,000 to examine the material?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. My attention has been drawn to the article which I have here. It is headed `Mike's private war-Vietnam veteran takes his fight to Canberra'. The Vietnam veteran is Mike Schar. He is very concerned that he cannot see the transcript of evidence in Adelaide. It was reported that he was told that he would have to fly to Canberra to view the transcript and that he would have to pay 5c per page-it is a document of 6,500 pages-and $2 a sitting. He had also been told it would cost him between $1,000 and $9,000.

ANSWER.PARA: I am happy to announce to the House-and especially to the honourable member-that there is a transcript of evidence in South Australia. It will be available in my Department's office there next week. So if the Vietnam veteran mentioned would like to go to my office and see the officers, they will make that transcript available to him. I do not know how long it will take him to sit down and read it, but I am sure the honourable member for Hawker will be happy to pass on to the Vietnam veteran that it will be at no cost whatsoever to him and he will not have to fly to Canberra either.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER: VISIT TO THE SOVIET UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister a question about his imminent trip to the Soviet Union. Is it correct, as announced by the leader of the Soviet parliamentary delegation to Australia last week, that the Australian Government intends to sign a general trade agreement with the Soviet Union? Is this agreement a wide-ranging one, which includes six individual bilateral agreements, with agreements on sporting contacts, research and human contacts? If so, can the Prime Minister inform the House as to what, if any, undertakings have been given in relation to the human contacts agreement by the Soviet Union concerning the rights of Soviet Jewry and Christian prisoners in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics? Will the Prime Minister, on his trip, be lobbying Soviet authorities on the rights and freedoms of Soviet Jewry and the release of more than 400 Christian prisoners incarcerated for the mere crime of practising their religion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am not going to go into all the details of the discussions that have gone on to this point in regard to the number of areas in which we will be seeking to conclude agreements with the Soviet Union. However, I assure the honourable member that I will continue the work that I and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade have done since we have been in office on the question of the rights of Soviet Jewry and human rights in the Soviet Union in general. The honourable gentleman will be aware-I know of his interest in this subject-of the success we have had in the positive responses by the Soviet authorities to the lists that I have put to the Soviet Union and that Madam Speaker also put to the Soviet Union on her visit there.

ANSWER.PARA: We welcome the improvement in the numbers of people who have been able to leave the Soviet Union. Soviet Jews have been asking for that right. We believe that more can be done. Therefore, I can assure the honourable gentleman that I will be pursuing this matter. PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Lyne Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens, of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, of Australia respectfully showeth:

Cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
We are concerned that-

(b) the abolition of CEP and the inadequacy of other training programs and

that the community will be done a disservice as it will lose the nationally proud young citizens that are helping to strengthen the defence forces;

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to provide efficient delivery of social services leading to the spread of poverty.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-
Mr Howe-Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. Does the honourable member for Bradfield have to be in the chamber to open his speech? He seems to have disappeared.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without the honourable member for Bradfield I doubt that the matter can be called on.
—Order! Without the honourable member for Bradfield the matter cannot be called on.
—I call the honourable member for Bradfield.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some years ago this country's Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:

SPEECH.PARA: The challenges and responsibilities confronting us in the coming years are profound-let us ensure that by acting constructively together we discharge those responsibilities in a way that will secure full employment and a better standard of living for all people.
In his Australian Labor Party (ALP) policy speech of 13 November 1984, he said:
We offer a continuing, coherent program-a firm ordering of priorities to build a prosperous, fair and caring society.

After five Budgets and numerous promises, it is not unreasonable that the Opposition should now take the Government to task on these issues. Right across the spectrum of statistics the same sorry story can be told. Let us look at domestic interest rates. Home loans in March 1983 were 12.5 per cent. In September this year they had risen to 15 per cent. The small overdraft rate had gone from 14 per cent to 19.25 per cent. Bankruptcies are surely one of the criteria for judging the success of an economic policy and the failure of a social policy. In 1982-83 there were 6,035 bankruptcies; in 1986-87 the number had grown to 8,597. Savings bank interest rates for March 1983 went from 12.5 per cent to 15.5 per cent, and the average home loan repayment as a percentage of median family income has risen from 19.2 per cent to 26.9 per cent. All the Government has done to solve that problem is to offer the poor a benefit of a mere $15 a week, which will have no impact whatsoever in the cities of Sydney and Melbourne.

Public housing waiting lists-another criterion which has to be looked at to judge whether or not a government's economic and social policies have been successful-show the same depressing trend. In December 1982 there were 110,000 people on the public housing waiting lists. By December 1986-to which the most recent figures apply-the figure had risen to 154,000. Those waiting lists have increased by some 50 per cent since 1982. Even after the latest tax cuts, single income earners and families will be paying 42c and 57c in the dollar respectively more tax than when Labor came to power. So much for a policy based on the need to give the Australian people compassion and concern-especially concern for those who need support most.

The ALP has claimed that old age pensions have improved across the board. But the reality is that, although they have now reached some 24.8 per cent of average weekly earnings, the purchasing power of average weekly earnings has fallen. As a result, it is no longer accurate to say that they are closer to that base than they were previously. The purchasing power of money under Labor has gone in one direction over five years, and that is consistently and inexorably down.

The issue is quite clear: the Australian people today are clearly worse off than they were at the change of government. We recognise the reality that 1982 was a hard year for Australia. We had a massive problem with the drought and other matters. But the simple fact is that the promises made by Labor then and since-the promises which have been repeated over five Budgets-have simply not been delivered upon. Today we have 824,700 Australian children living in poverty. In 1982 there were 660,000. No one on this side of the House takes any joy whatsoever at that figure. But the simple fact is that the social policies of this Government have made the situation worse and not better.

Now, after five Budgets, the Government has finally decided to bring in a family package-a package which was thrown together just before the last election, clearly with political intentions in mind, to try to shore up its own support in that range of seats in the western suburbs of Sydney and parts of Melbourne, where its own supporters are no longer prepared to believe that the Labor Party is one of compassion and concern and that the Labor Party is concerned about their affairs. These people voted in the only way open to them-they voted against Labor at the last Federal election. That trend has been emphasised since then by the Government's own Treasurer (Mr Keating), who made the point in his speech in Melbourne last week that the time has come for the Labor Party to try to win back its traditional support. The people who provide that traditional support, together with the middle income earners of Australia, have every reason to say that the situation is much worse today under Labor. Even the Prime Minister has said in this House and elsewhere that standards of living in Australia are falling. I will go further and say that, regrettably, standards of living in Australia under this Government will continue to fall.

Let us look at the family debt crisis. Family debt amounts to $23 billion as a direct result of the Labor Government's policies which have taxed Australian families into poverty. The erosion of the relative tax position of middle income families is a disgrace. It is shown by the fact that every family is now carrying on average a debt of $6,000 to banks and lending institutions. That represents a 40 per cent increase in the last 12 months. Families today are committing 69 per cent of their weekly income to paying debts. It is the highest proportion for many years, yet once again this Government tries to delude people into believing that change is here, that we have nothing more to worry about, that the worst is behind us so let us proceed forward. The procession to the future will simply be a repetition of the disasters of the past.

The National Institute of Economic and Industry Research pointed out that the number of Australians living in poverty has increased during the 1980s, that there has been a significant increase in poverty from 1981-82 to 1985-86, that the most important increases have occurred among families with two or more children and that the bigger the family, the higher the incidence of poverty. It is a fact which the Government, regrettably, has not adequately taken into account in its family package. The Institute also pointed out that the group with the highest poverty, which represents 31 per cent is that consisting of families with four or more children and that the next group in poverty is that consisting of single people aged 15 to 24, representing 26 per cent. The Institute study used the Henderson poverty line as its base. Maybe the Minister is not satisfied with the Henderson poverty line. If the Government is not prepared to accept the basis of the Henderson analysis after five Budgets, surely it is time it developed a new poverty line. That clearly has not been its purpose because to do so would almost certainly show a worse situation than that which is already known.

The Institute also pointed out that families with three or more children are hard hit because increases in the poverty line have outstripped increases in the family allowance. While the allowance has risen at a greater rate than the poverty line for families with two children or one child, the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS), for example, was critical of the Federal Government's failure to index supplementary payments to pensioners and beneficiaries. In an answer to a question today from his own side, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) alleged that ACOSS had no problems with the family package policy. I draw the Minister's attention to an article by Glenn Milne headed `Maintenance plan opposition grows' which states:

The president of ACOSS, Mr Julian Disney, met with the Social Security Minister, Mr Howe, and told him the welfare lobby could not support the child support scheme unless income tests governing the payment of maintenance were relaxed and sole parents were given guaranteed basic maintenance.

So much for the Minister's allegation that ACOSS is on his side. Quite clearly, from Julian Disney's own discussions with the Minister, ACOSS has very real and genuine problems in this area, problems which I have emphasised in this place and elsewhere. The Government has created a whole range of poverty traps which it has made no attempt to overcome. Now, in some cases, people will be paying over 100 per cent more tax on a dollar basis because of being able to have access to various benefits under this package.

The value of the family allowance has in fact fallen by 29 per cent over recent years. The Minister has made the situation even worse by cutting it out at age 16. Where is the Minister's belief in horizontal equity? We can say as an Opposition that this Government has no belief in horizontal equity. Yet it is one of the very basic principles of any social security policy which must be taken into account. The Minister has gone out of his way to take out of the tax system any means of supporting families. He is working on the presumption that those who need the most support are those who pay little, if any, tax. The fact is that there are many taxpayers who are just above the poverty line who have large families and who are getting very little support from this child package which has been put forward by the Government.

Another point I want to make in this debate is that the Government's handling of a whole range of policies in relation to the Department of Social Security leaves much to be desired. I recommended to members of this House that they read the two reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the various difficulties that the Department has faced over recent years.

The simple fact is that the industrial relations record of the Department of Social Security since 1983 has been a disgrace. Throughout 1984 and 1985 every conceivable form of industrial resistance was brought in, especially against the Stratplan project objectives over that period. The Government was forced into a situation in which it finally had to agree with staff associations on the Stratplan and associated automatic data processing developments. The agreement is an extraordinary document which I recommend that honourable members read. It shows quite clearly that the Government backed down. Why did it back down? It did so because in the initial stages it did not even bother to negotiate with its employees or to discuss with them precisely what it wanted. Having stirred up the possum, it naturally created further difficulties for the trade union movement. The only way it could get its program moving at all was effectively to sign this agreement. It was nothing more than a give-away on a whole range of things. For example, on the question of compulsory redeployment, it states:
Should the need arise for compulsory redeployment, the Department undertakes that:
(i) staff will not be required to move domicile as part of any redeployment process:
(ii) there will be no compulsory transfers of staff between a country town or country city to a metropolitan area or to another country town or country city:
(iii) in any consideration of the need to compulsorily transfer any individual staff:
(1) each case shall be considered on its merit, taking into account:
excessive travelling time:
extra costs:
availability of transport:

It is an extraordinary document, demonstrating once again the fact that the employers, in this case the Commonwealth using taxpayers' money, have effectively lost control of the machinery of government. The staff associations concerned with the industrial disputes were especially involved in health and staffing level reallocation. In October 1984 there were problems. Later in the same month we had a continuation of the situation. The simple fact is that the Department was not able to plan ahead. It did not anticipate having these difficulties with the changes introduced. Consequently, there was a two-day strike, work bans over compensation, closure on Wednesday afternoons, a ban on incoming phone calls and a veto on anti-fraud measures-the very same measures introduced by the Minister in an attempt to overcome the problems raised by the Opposition over the last two years about the degree of fraud and overpayment taking place throughout the system. There were rolling strikes. There was tension among staff of the Commonwealth Employment Service; it reached the stage where they would not even talk to each other on some occasions. Claims relating to repetitive strain injury (RSI) got out of all control. In fact 15 per cent of claims within the Public Service relate to RSI within the Department of Social Security. Annual radiation tests on visual display units were demanded, costing over $100,000. In spite of all this, the Minister then provides 500 additional staff at the very time when one of the criteria behind the introduction of Stratplan was that there would be a significant saving both financially and in terms of employment positions.

The reality is that the Minister has not been able to administer his Department, to introduce the changes and to tighten up the procedures. Those of us who have been to the Department of Social Security offices have seen that access to unemployment benefit is still too loose. I have seen people standing at the counter, and the only test put to them was, `What attempts have you made to find employment?'. The answer was, `I have read a newspaper'. These people were well dressed and well spoken and in my frank opinion should have made a much more determined effort to seek a job.

The social security area is of massive importance. It accounts for some 28 per cent of all Federal Government expenditure. It represents to a large extent the capacity of a government and an opposition to be able to apply their philosophy to maintain all Australian people in a state of dignity and with compassion. That does not mean that we encourage people to have access to social security. The simple fact is that it is very difficult through a social security system alone to be able to improve people's overall economic position and self-worth. The only way to achieve that is through an interaction between social security policies and economic policies.

I come back to where I began: this Government has failed in its economic policies. We have now reached the situation of having more people below the poverty line, despite the Government's much heralded family package, than this nation has known. It is not a record of which any government can be proud. It is certainly not a record. The Australian Labor Party claims that compassion and concern are the hallmarks of its activities; here it has lost an appropriate sense of direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very surprising that the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), in his inaugural matter of public importance in his current position as spokesperson on social security, should have raised so little of substance in his speech. The Government's extraordinarily honourable record in the area of public housing is also hardly a matter for social security, although in passing I have to point out that, in terms of the number of houses built and the number of housing starts, no government has a better record than the current Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member complains about the fact that pensioners receive only 24.8 per cent of average weekly earnings. Let me compare that with the 22.8 per cent of average weekly earnings that they received when the conservatives were in office. Of course that is a measure of relative standard of living, and it indicates that there was a devaluation of the real standard of living of pensioners under the previous Government. He talks of the family package as being something that was thrown together at the last moment. He ignores the fact that the genesis of the family package was in very extensive research work carried out as part of the Social Security Review chaired by Professor Cass. He neglects to mention that the short term policy recommendations of the Cass review were carried out in their entirety by the Government. This was no short term package, but indeed was put together as a result of a very significant review of aspects of the social security system. As in other areas of government change, those changes will reflect an overall approach often in line with the work being done by Professor Cass in her review.

The honourable member for Bradfield made reference to increases in poverty. I think any student of the subject of poverty within the Australian community would be well aware that real poverty increased along with the increase in unemployment that occurred between 1976 and 1983. That is when a massive growth occurred in the number of people unemployed, and increasingly those people who were unemployed had dependent children. It was also during the Opposition's period in office that we saw a very significant growth in the number of sole parents. The number increased at about 11 per cent per annum, for example in 1976 and 1977, and in 1983-84 it was still 4 per cent per annum. In the period we have been in government we have seen a diminution in the rate of increase and, indeed in the last financial year, a real decrease in the number of sole parents. Between 1976 and 1983 we saw a massive blowout of unemployment and a very significant increase, at least a doubling, of the number of sole parents. During that time we saw a growth in the number of children in pensioner and beneficiary families, from a little over 300,000 to about 800,000. So when we came into government in 1983 one in every five children was effectively in a pensioner and beneficiary family.

Faced with that situation, what has the Government sought to do? First of all, it sought to put Australians back to work. That was the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1983, and it is a commitment that the Labor governments have honoured. We have seen a growth of nearly 900,000 jobs in the period we have been in government, a rate of job creation twice the level of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries; it is a better record of job creation than almost any other country in the OECD. That is a statistic that the honourable member for Bradfield chose to ignore, because it is unfavourable to his case. Similarly, he ignored the Government's record with respect to inflation. We inherited an inflation rate which was running well over 10 per cent. Inflation has been substantially reduced, despite difficult circumstances, during the period that we have been in office. Again, he failed to mention that fact.

In terms of the record with respect to employment and unemployment, of course, it is just as important that we reduce the number of people who are in receipt of the unemployment benefit. If we look at the most recent statistic, we will see that on 10 November 1987 there were 484,000 people in receipt of the unemployment benefit-a fall of 50,000 since November 1986. If one compares the present figure for average rates of beneficiaries with that for 1984-85, there has been a fall from 581,000 to 520,000 in the current year. Not only has employment grown, but the number of people in receipt of the unemployment benefit has reduced steadily over the period that we have been in government, and at a somewhat increased rate during the last 12 months.

The coalition's policy, during difficult circumstances, when increasing numbers of people were unemployed, rather than maintaining a real level of benefit, sought to reduce the level of assistance to those who were unemployed, and particularly to reduce the real level of assistance to those who were unemployed with dependent children. Similarly the coalition, with respect to sole parents, rather than providing additional assistance to people on a class A widow's pension or a supporting parent's benefit during the period that it was in government, reduced that assistance very significantly. So the real value, for example, of payments for pensioner beneficiaries' children fell by over 30 per cent during the period that it was in government.

It might be argued that that was perhaps an aberration, that the philosophy of the coalition at that time was a harsher philosophy than what might be expected from a present coalition government. Indeed, in a recent speech in the House, the honourable member for Bradfield recalled the marvellous dream of the Menzies years and said that that was the tradition to which the coalition might adhere today. Of course, during the marvellous traditions of the Menzies years, there was no supporting parent's benefit, and nothing equivalent to today's class A widow's pension.

Let me refer to what the coalition's policies were at the most recent election in respect of sole parents. The honourable member for Bradfield has just put out a Press statement describing some of the measures that the Government has taken, with respect to reducing the qualifying age of a child of sole parents to 15, as harsh. In the course of this Press release he failed to mention that the coalition went into the most recent election saying that it would reduce the age for the qualifying child to the age of 10-that is, one gets a pension if one has a child under the age of 10; if the child is over 10, one does not get a pension. That was the policy that was announced. Of course, it would now like to walk away from that policy. Having announced it a few weeks ago, it now wants to forget it. The coalition does not like to be reminded of its history and it does not even like to be reminded of its current policies. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), recently said that, if a coalition government came into office, it would single out sole parents and the unemployed for special attention. Sole parents would be the victims and would pay the price of a coalition government.

It is suggested by the honourable member for Bradfield that there has not been a reduction in poverty during the period that we have been in government and that, indeed, we have not made progress towards any anti-poverty objectives. Of course, when we came into office, a single pensioner beneficiary with two children and who rented privately was $28.10 per week, or 20 per cent, below the poverty line. In December 1987 that gap will be reduced to $3.95 per week, or 1.9 per cent. A married pensioner couple with three children renting privately were $7.65 per week, or 3.9 per cent, below the poverty line. In December they will be $3.55 per week, or 1.2 per cent, above the poverty line. A married beneficiary couple with three children renting privately was $21.50 per week, or 11 per cent, below the poverty line. In December they will be $3.55 per week above the poverty line. The December figures are still higher where children are aged 13 to 15 with an additional payment of $6.

When Labor came into office poverty among pensioner and beneficiary families with children and in rented accommodation was scandalous. These people have been our priority ever since. The Government has substantially reduced the poverty gap and already raised many groups above that level. The Government has seriously addressed poverty among working families with children. Almost everyone in the community has enthusiastically supported the family allowance supplement which comes into effect two weeks from tomorrow.

The honourable member for Bradfield said that we should pay more attention to horizontal equity. At a time when there has been wage restraint and when large numbers of people live in very low income households, the Government is right to put much greater emphasis on vertical equity. But at the same time the honourable member said that larger families would receive little or no benefit from the Government's policies. Is $28 per child or $22 per child a recognition of horizontal equity, a recognition of the significance of extending assistance to larger families?

Against that we must recall what the Opposition has suggested. It has been on about horizontal equity to the tune of over a billion dollars in its family package, but the assistance foreshadowed by the Opposition was a maximum not of $15 per child but $15 per family. Not one cent of that $15 would go to a sole parent family. The poorest group in the Australian community, sole parents, would not be given a red cent by the honourable member for Bradfield. He is prepared to go around the welfare sector and to bleat and whine and suggest that somehow the Government is being unfair and unjust, but in the recent election he defended a party which intended to wipe out benefit for sole parents with children over the age of 10, a party that was offering a family package costing more than a billion dollars but with not a cent for sole parents and their children.

If Opposition members are to talk about equity and social justice, they will have to change that policy. That policy is extremely unfair and shows no commitment to the poor. Honourable members can go to the Smith Family and St Vincent de Paul as much as they like, but if they say that they will go into the next election on the basis of a policy that would wipe out assistance to supporting parents with children over the age of 11 and not provide a cent to a sole parent family in their family package, let us see how they would fare in the welfare sector.

The honourable member for Bradfield can be as glib, smooth and sensitive as he likes-he is certainly an improvement on the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt)-but the reality is that his policies are not believable in terms of compassion, sympathy and understanding. The Opposition's policy in the recent election involved sticking a boot into sole parents and of not giving support to family types Opposition members did not like. The Opposition's policy gave no additional assistance to low income families and there was no sense of targeting assistance, from a party with a record of diminishing living standards for the poorest group in the community year in and year out. In the coalition's period of government there was a massive increase in unemployment, the numbers of sole parents increased, and one in every five children were living in poverty. This Government makes no apology: those children are our priority. We are delivering to those children. In every Budget we have increased payments and now we are committed to indexation and to a lift in the standard of living of low income earners.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is discussing as a matter of public importance the alleged failure of the Government to provide efficient delivery of social services leading to the spread of poverty. It stands to reason that when we consider a budgetary outlay of virtually $23 billion-that is, 29.8 per cent of total outlays-we realise immediately that any inefficiency adds up to very substantial sums of money.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also mindful that at first blush the proposition invites argument insofar as, over the last decade or so, governments of all colours have poured thousands of millions of dollars into relieving the needy only to find that the needy become more needy and numerous. Therefore, the term `efficient delivery' is the nub of the matter. It is not necessarily efficient delivery in a negative sense but efficient delivery in a positive sense. Insofar as circumstances and conditions predispose a situation where the government of the day must put increasing demand on the taxpayers-those employed-to accommodate those unemployed, increasing demands on our economy to meet the expectations of society have become divorced from the harsh reality that invariably there is a substantial gulf between expectation and entitlement. There is considerable truth in the remarks of another that when governments set out to relieve the citizens of their responsibilities, they in fact do not serve the citizens; they betray them.

In his remarks, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) used statistical data, which I do not particularly challenge, and asked, `What are your policies for the next election?'. That touches on the raw nerve because within the parameters of democratic government, governments and aspiring governments have a predisposition to concentrate on that which might conceivably enhance their electoral prospects, but not necessarily the economic and social well-being of our country. In that respect we have failed as a parliament to deliver services efficiently because we have imbued the recipients with the notion that, somehow or other, governments in the ultimate can relieve them of their responsibilities. Without being devoid of compassion, I question the point of an increase in family allowances if, in all too many instances, this simply has the effect of buying a few more stubbies and a few more packets of cigarettes to dull the agony arising from the sense of futility in present circumstances. That is not an efficient delivery of services. The Government is the government of the day. There is no point in charging oppositions with their past derelictions. The game continually changes and the Government has the responsibility for making pragmatic judgments as to what is necessary for the social well-being of our community.

I venture to say that there would be no demur whatsoever within this House on the proposition that, on current trends of social welfare expenditure, by the mid 1990s there is no way that we will be able to foot the bill. We are in an ever decreasing circle which must inevitably lead to an explosion of our social and economic circumstances. That is inefficiency and irresponsibility. Putting the Government's electoral prospects aside-and our circumstances are such today that we can no longer luxuriate in our electoral ambitions-we must tell the country what is wrong with it. We must imbue our citizens both with a realisation and a resolve to co-operate with government to achieve that which will substantially relieve the need to succour those who, through real or imagined misfortune, have become conditioned, almost in a parasitical fashion, to living off government. Having used that expression, I stress that pensioners and the like cannot be categorised as such. But all too many have become conditioned to believe that the Government must preserve their expectations and their circumstances.

Again we see in evidence that virtually $200m has been outlaid for Aboriginal affairs in this Budget. Does it not strike the House as extraordinarily strange that, with the outgoings of thousands of millions of dollars since 1968, we have a situation today in which those with an empathy for the Aboriginals or those with a mischievous intent, seeing the opportunity to stir up social discord, can plead the shocking circumstances of the Aborigine? What has gone wrong? Clearly the money has been misplaced or it has not achieved its intended objective. It has further reduced our society to a state of disarray.

The Government has the responsibility to come clean, to use simple terms, with our society and with welfare beneficiaries, and say, `There is only one way we can relieve your dilemma in the end, and that is for you to accept the circumstances in which the country is placed'. We have to give people the opportunity to paddle their own canoes. We have the notion that we should be maintained in our own circumstances, or own environment. Unhappily, I am old enough to remember that in the 1930s-I must insist that I was a child of very tender years-people took to the roads. They walked from one end of the country to another looking for a job. Perish the thought that we should ever return to those circumstances. It was a state of mind. Now if one cannot get a job in one's own backyard somehow or another one is immured from the responsibility of looking for work. We suffer from a social malaise, inevitable because of the good circumstances we enjoyed post-war. It is a sad commentary on our society and on man as a creature that historically whenever he has had a full belly he has had an empty head. He is blinded to the reality of the circumstances which should dictate his fortune. If the Government picks up the challenge to acquaint society, the poor, the oppressed-all people-of the need to develop the right attitude to our country's future, the Minister and the Parliament will find how much more effectively the brain starts to function when the navel gets closer to the backbone. Until we realise our circumstances we will not move from them.

There is an inefficient delivery of services. We are relieving our citizens of their responsibilities. We are imbuing them with the notion that somehow or other government will look after them. But government cannot look after them on a continuing basis. The day will arrive when we have total disarray. Those in good jobs, earning $800 to $900 a week, will be totally indifferent to the well-being of their fellow workers in the same industry. If a company becomes non-viable, is there any suggestion that the workers may adjust their salaries to the economic parameters of the company to keep their colleagues in employment? Not on your sweet nellie. They will maintain the conditions they enjoy, disregarding the fact that the best job conditions on earth are not worth a crumpet if they have the effect of putting their employer out of business. They would rather see their colleagues go on the unemployment list than meet their predicament and, therefore, enjoy, across the broad, a better social situation.

The proposition put by the Opposition today devolves on the words `efficient delivery'. We are not talking about an unending supply of money and it is just a question of to whom we will give it and how we will give it. The Government is deluding the electorate into believing that there is an unending supply of money to accommodate its expectations and is betraying it in the process. For too many years now, for reasons I have alluded to, we have gone on enhancing our electoral prospects, deluding society into believing that what it seeks is synonymous with what it is entitled to. In that respect the Government's policies are becoming increasingly inefficient because we have gone further down the track.

We are wiser than we were a decade ago, or five years ago. But we perpetuate this nonsense of engaging in the inefficient delivery of social services and inefficiently addressing our economic problems on the premise that somehow or other it will all work out in the end, that things will fall into place and that we will escape the penalty we should attach to our folly. If this country persists in the notion that by taxing more heavily and by engaging in total economic and social irresponsibility people can be accorded what they wish for, as history tells us all to clearly, the end will be totally predictable-we will have a total breakdown of our society.

He worked himself into a lather with ludicrous claims that this Government is the only group in society that is responsible for poverty. I find it a little strange that the honourable member for Bradfield, the current shadow Minister for Social Security, the man who just launched the matter of public importance today, represents perhaps the richest electorate in Australia. He comes from the North Shore of Sydney, an area in which, I understand, since the stock market crash there has been increased interest in the extent of poverty. He represents suburbs such as St Ives, Lindfield and Killara.

I often question the depth of knowledge of the honourable member for Bradfield which was demonstrated in a debate on social security legislation last week. In that debate he confused the suburbs of Mount Druitt and Campbelltown. To help the honourable member for Bradfield to understand the difference between poverty in areas such as Mount Druitt, Campbelltown and my electorate and Bradfield, I have asked the Parliamentary Library to dig up some statistics on the proportion of families with incomes of less than $12,000.
