In the electorates of Chifley and Werriwa, covering Mount Druitt and Campbelltown respectively, one in six families has an income of less than $12,000. In my own electorate of Dobell one in four families has an income of less than $12,000. Given those statistics, I can understand the honourable member for Bradfield, who represents the very wealthy North Shore areas, not appreciating the extent of poverty in our community.

The honourable member for Bradfield was a member of this Parliament during the Fraser years. What was the Fraser Government's record on poverty? What did it do to stop poverty increasing? It successfully increased the number of people receiving pensions and benefits from 300,000 to 800,000. That was the result of a massive increase in unemployment following the collapse in Australia's internal economy. That was the previous Government's contribution to the fight against poverty. Australia's industrial infrastructure collapsed. The steel industry was going out of business. The dollar was fixed and overvalued, which meant that Australian producers could not compete on world markets.

Since this Labor Government has been in office we have had, not a reduction in employment of 100,000 which we saw under the previous Government, but an increase of nearly 900,000 jobs, which the Minister for Social Security has pointed out is nearly twice the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. That demonstrates that this Government can hold its head high in the world. Under the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, we have had plans for the car industry, the steel industry, the ship building industry and, of course, the heavy industry package, which will ensure that employment continues to expand. What better way to raise a family out of poverty than to ensure that the main breadwinner has a job?

This Government can rightly claim that its new proposal to introduce a family allowance supplement is a reform of historic proportions. It continues a great Labor tradition which was begun in the 1930s by people such as Jack Lang in New South Wales and was continued by the Curtin and Whitlam Labor governments. I believe that the family allowance supplement will fulfil the Labor Government's promise to ensure that no Australian child need live in poverty. The way we will do that is to target the families who are the poorest. We will try to direct the Government's scarce resources to those who are in greatest need. Many people are not aware of the great amounts of tax free cash which they will be able to receive through the family allowance supplement. Many people are not aware that from December they will receive up to $22 per week per child for children under 13 years of age and, because it costs more to raise a teenager, families with children between 13 and 15 years old will receive $28 per week per child, again tax free. Those families will receive an additional $15 per week if they are renting privately.

This family allowance supplement will benefit more than 200,000 working families in the community and will provide a real increase in the standard of living for more than one million Australian children. That is something of which any Labor government can be rightly proud. In addition, a very important reform is that the income test of the new family allowance supplement is more generous than that on the family income supplement scheme which it has replaced. I will give two examples. A family with a gross income of $400 per week with two teenagers and renting will receive $27 a week tax free. This is equivalent to a pay increase, which is taxable, of $45 a week. The same family on $350 a week gross income will receive $52 a week tax free. The family allowance supplement will provide great benefits to working families.

In addition, this Government has not neglected the pensioners. The base rate of the pension has been increased from $77 a week, which is what it was when honourable members opposite left office, and from mid-December this year it will be $116.10 a week. The honourable member for Bradfield incorrectly claimed that this Government made promises that were never delivered. He gave the old example that this Government had not raised pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. What was the record of the Liberals when they were in government? Pensions fell to 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings in the Fraser years. That was the Opposition's record. Pensions fell from the high of the Whitlam years, when they were 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, to only 22.7 per cent under the Liberals. Under this Government and this Minister for Social Security the base rate of the pension has been raised to 24.8 per cent of average weekly earnings, a great achievement.

We have carried out other reforms. We have relaxed the income text, abolished taking separate income into account for rental allowance and, as part of the Government's family package, we are increasing the child supplement which is paid to pensioners so that they will receive $22 per week per child under 13 years of age and $28 per week for those children between 13 and 15 years of age. The Opposition has a lot of gall to seek to argue that this Government has not done enough to reduce poverty when its record shows that it created a great problem which this Government has addressed. Any Labor government could be very proud of the reforms which this Government and this Minister have introduced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to expand the powers of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation to include a wider range of banking and investment services as well as to introduce other measures to increase the effectiveness of the bank's operations. At this point, and bearing in mind the intervention of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), I should state an interest; I am a satisfied client of the Commonwealth Bank. It is maintained by the Government that these changes will improve the competitiveness of the Commonwealth banks and enhance their profitability and should give rise to increased dividend payments in future years. However, these amendments will not address the fundamental inadequacies involved in public ownership of otherwise purely commercial operations.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past public enterprises have become capital deficient because governments have failed to set the correct expenditure priorities. Therefore, whilst the Opposition will not be opposing the Bill, I will be moving the following second reading amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House (a) notes the undercapitalisation of the Commonwealth Bank and the subsequent constraints this imposes on its efficient administration, and (b) calls upon the Government to undertake a review to assess whether the sale of the Commonwealth Bank would be in the best interests of the Australian people'.

Why do we raise the issue of privatising the Commonwealth Bank? The Opposition has decided to review this question. In our schedule of publicly owned assets, businesses and corporations that we believe ought to be privatised, the Commonwealth Bank is not listed. Therefore, we have determined, particularly in view of matters that I will raise, namely, the undercapitalisation of the bank, the need to examine whether the bank ought also to be privatised. The amendment which I will move calls upon the Government to do the same. Whilst not denying the passage of the Bill, we will move the amendment and, amongst other things, suggest that, in view of remarks to which I will refer later, particularly by Senator Gareth Evans who referred to the undercapitalisation of bodies such as Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank, it is now timely with this Bill before us that this matter of privatising the bank be reviewed.

There appears to be more than a few problems with the bank. Only last week we saw Press reports of a decision by the Commonwealth Bank to reduce the number of staff by up to 5,000 over the next four years as a direct result of the Government's refusal to address adequately the bank's capital base funding needs. However, before I go into more detail on this issue, let me provide a brief synopsis of the major features of the bank. The bank provides a range of commercial and savings bank services. As at June 1987 it had some 33,071 full time staff and 5,124 part time employees. The bank has the largest network of branches and agencies of the four major banks in Australia. In June this year it had 1,273 branches and 5,131 agencies. The Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia enjoys approximately a one-third share of the savings bank market in Australia, and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia enjoys approximately 20 per of the trading bank business.

For the financial year 1986-87, the Commonwealth banking group reported a net profit after tax of $197.2m; that is in fact down some 33 per cent on the previous year's result. Admittedly, the 1985-86 result was particularly good. The result for that year was in large measure due to substantially high foreign exchange earnings. Indeed, research has shown, and I note the work by Mr Paul Coughlin, an investment analyst, on this topic, that in the last decade the Commonwealth Bank, compared with its three major privately owned competitors, has regrettably-I say `regrettably' because I declared my interest by saying that I am a satisfied customer of the bank-shown consistently lower rates of asset growth, consistently lower rates of return on assets, consistently lower rates of return on equity and consistently lower earnings per employee. These are the real measures of success, or lack of it, of the bank.

Over the same period the net return of the Commonwealth Bank to its owners is very poor compared with the record of, say, the National Australia Bank Ltd, a slightly smaller bank but one with a similar emphasis on retail branch borrowing. Some will agree that these results simply reflect the focus of the Commonwealth bank, as a so-called people's bank, on providing a concessionary structure of fees and charges. However, the figures show that there is little difference between the charging policies of the Commonwealth Bank and its major competitors. The answer seems to lie more in the costlier operating practices.

One of the contributors to these problems is the inadequate capital base. In December last year in a letter to the Australian Financial Review, the then Managing Director of the Bank, Mr Vernon Christie, registered public concern that the non-availability of capital was hampering the bank's growth strategies. Indeed, a recent report by Mr Greg Crough of the University of Sydney, prepared on behalf of the bank's own in-house union, the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, shows deep concern for the need for reform. It is interesting, and to some I would think surprising, that even that union paper is prepared to canvass the possibility of a partial sale of the bank. However, I am intrigued to note that while the paper produced for the union claims to `oppose vigorously any moves to privatisation' it is happy to talk in terms of commercialisation or corporatisation. It seems to me to be a rose by any other name. There seems to be an inability to deal with the term `privatisation' on the part of those influenced by honourable members opposite, who for so long denigrated the Opposition for proposing privatisation but are now themselves so doing-to put it rhetorically, facing themselves, it would appear, coming the other way.

A rose by any other name is a fair description of the Government's attitude because we all know that the Australian Labor Party is not into plain speaking in this day and age, particularly on this subject. It is at sixes and sevens over the whole privatisation debate. We all recall the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) raising a diabolical spectre in relation to those who supported privatisation. He sought to paint a monstrous prospect. He did so in this very House on 21 November 1985. I quote the Prime Minister:
They know, as anyone who thinks about the issue of privatisation knows, that it would mean higher prices, higher costs, higher taxes and higher fares-

all of which, I might add, the Government has already managed to bring about quite well. In the period of this Government Australians have experienced the highest of prices, costs, taxes and fares. All of this has come about under this biggest spending and highest taxing government in the history of Australia. After the recent election, this very same Prime Minister, who exuded condemnation of privatisation in any form, began to talk-it was only a couple of months ago-of the absolute necessity of reviewing the Government's privatisation policy. I will not worry here about the fact that his senior Ministers seemed more than a little confused about the manner in which the Prime Minister initiated the debate. I can remember both hearing on television and reading in newspapers the comments of Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Button, those Ministers carrying the major responsibility for bodies ripe for sale, criticising the current Prime Minister for his lack of finesse and, indeed, for his blundering style-and well they might on this issue. Black, in the Prime Minister's mind, has quite correctly become white. But that is their criticism, not just ours.

What of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? The man who would be king was silent on this matter, just as he was on the Australia Card. Despite the arguments of the enormous economic benefits that, according to this Government, would allegedly flow from the Australia Card, we have heard precious little from the man who would be king regarding privatisation, perhaps until recently-although honourable members will recall that when we were seeking to determine where he stands on this issue, he said in this House on 23 August 1985:
The Prime Minister, other Ministers and I have made it abundantly clear that we see no case for the so-called privatisation of the great public enterprises of this country.

Well, the Treasurer could not possibly be switching his views in the current era, could he-not once again after the negative gearing switch, the foreign investment switch and the capital gains switch? He said that we would never have a capital gains tax but then we had one. One gets the impression of one Minister spinning like a top. However, there are reports in some papers today, certainly in yesterday's Sydney Sun-Herald, that in a submission to Cabinet the Treasurer now indicates that public enterprises will need to be sold if they are to achieve the necessary market discipline and management. This Government has shown an extraordinary propensity to plagiarise the policies of the current Opposition. Yet again, in the twilight of its term-notwithstanding having just been returned to government-it sees the reality and the strength of the Opposition's arguments in favour of privatisation. All we ask in regard to the Commonwealth Bank is not that there be an announcement that the bank will be privatised, but that the Government will set about a review of the possibility of privatising the bank and recognise what its own Ministers are telling it-that the bank is undercapitalised.

The submission I have just referred to is also reported as indicating that there is little alternative if the Government wishes to avoid a blowout in the borrowing requirement of Commonwealth authorities under Loan Council arrangements. Last week in an address to a conference, the topic of which was `Privatisation in Australia', Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Transport and Communications, to whom I referred earlier, said:

One merely has to multiply the scenario elsewhere to contemplate a quite major budgetary problem looming ahead for the Government: from three enterprises alone-Qantas, Australian Airlines and (if it is to broaden its asset base) the Commonwealth Bank-the budgetary outlay required will be, over the next few years, of the order of $1 billion.

At this moment what I am concerned about is the reason why the Government is so obviously changing its story. I doubt whether the real reasons in fact have much to do with the allocative efficiency of resources. The reasons lie more at the heart of the Government's inability appropriately to address the need for outlay reductions. The Government is scared of the prospect of payments from the Budget because it knows that it has not made, nor is it prepared to make, enough quality cuts in expenditure to provide room for more legitimate types of capital expenditure such as these. It is obvious that a main reason for the Government now contemplating privatisation is that it has forced itself into a corner. In fact, I am concerned that the Government, with the rate of enthusiasm it is showing for privatisation programs-albeit I endorse the reality that it is now looking at privatisation-may be forced into unnecessarily quick sales to the detriment of Australian taxpayers because of its inability to make the necessary outlay cuts elsewhere. Nevertheless, given these concerns and the fact that the Government's reasons are basically confused, the results it achieves by selling many of these authorities hold the prospect of being very beneficial.

We in the Opposition have always preferred free enterprise over government ownership. The associated incentives that involves will, in the main, deliver society its greatest potential. Our reasons for calling a review of the sale of the Commonwealth Bank come from the need for a calm and rational debate within the community. In the process, the return of a publicly owned asset to private hands will not be detrimental but rather advantageous to the consumer. It will remove further burdens from the taxpayer. In regard to that, in introducing the original Commonwealth Banks Bill in 1911, the then Labor Prime Minister, Andrew Fisher, who was also Treasurer, stated:
This will be a bank belonging to the people and directly managed by the people's agents.

These are nice sounding words but with great respect to Mr Fisher he also should have talked about the people's best interests. The question remains whether the public ownership of the bank is in fact in the best interests of the people. Basically, the value of public ownership of the bank to the Government is the present value of future dividend flows. It is certainly arguable that the sale of the bank would save more in interest payments, if the proceeds of the sale were used to reduce the public sector debt, then the Government would receive in dividends from the bank if it were not sold.

I again note that privatisation requires gradual implementation and thorough investigation of available options. We do not want any bargain basement sales. The Opposition, of course, has a set of guidelines on asset sales which we hope the Government will adopt. Firstly, there must be demonstrable benefits to consumers and/or taxpayers. Secondly, the position and job security of existing employees will be given special consideration and the sale of shares to employees will be encouraged wherever possible. Thirdly, the quality and availability of services to remote areas will not be allowed to deteriorate and any large-scale sales will be timed so as to avoid disruption of capital markets. Fourthly, sale proceeds will not be used to finance new government expenditure but will be directed towards reducing the accumulated public debt.

I stress that point because this year, in the phoney balanced Budget that the Treasurer brought forward, not only did the Government benefit from profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia but also it benefited from $1 billion from the sale of assets. It projected the proceeds of the sale to shore up its budgetary position rather than to service and retire our debt.

In the case of a possible sale of the Commonwealth Bank, the private shareholders would presumably be governed by the Banks (Shareholdings) Act which prevents any one shareholder or related shareholders from holding more than 15 per cent of shares. Normally, when we privatise an enterprise, we attach to the criteria what the British term a golden share, thus allowing the Australian Government to ensure that foreign interests could not have more than 50 per cent of the holding. We could exercise the golden share to ensure that the shares were held in the main by Australians. In the case of the banks that is not necessary because there is a 15 per cent and 10 per cent limit in any case without the Treasurer's intervention.

Before I conclude I wish to refer to two specific aspects of the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill. The Bill expands investment powers of the bank to put it on a more equal footing with the private commercial banks. We do not oppose such motives. Nevertheless, further analysis suggests that the expansions of the bank's powers to provide insurance services may raise concerns. The intention in clause 14 of the Bill is to allow the bank to provide modest insurance services so as to remain competitive with other banks. Our concern is based on the possibility that too wide a scope for expanding services will allow the potential establishment of a full blown government insurance office. This would be, in our view, an undesirable result. That is especially so in light of the blowout in State government owned insurance office net borrowings in recent years. In some States these offices have been incurring large deficits on an accrual basis in their compulsory third party motor vehicle insurance and workers compensation cases.

There is legitimate concern that these problems have arisen because government insurance offices have not been allowed to operate on purely commercial grounds. This is even more pressing given the involvement of the Burke Government in Western Australia in the operations of the Western Australia State Government Insurance Commission with respect to the rapid purchases of land and shares from struggling entrepreneurs. More than $500m of the Commission's funds are being used for that purpose. Therefore, the Opposition will be moving at the committee stage a series of amendments to ensure that the extended insurance services will be only those ancillary to other banking activity.

Finally, I note that the Bill introduces a dividend requirement from the Commonwealth Development Bank. The introduction of such a dividend policy is in itself reasonable on efficiency grounds. Nevertheless, given this Government's past record it appears that once again it has used this cover to introduce further revenue raising measures. This exercise simply looks like yet another grab for cash. As I said before, this Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history-some record! It is a record spending, record taxing government. The Government concentrates far too much on the revenue side of the Budget. It should be looking to recurrent expenditure reductions. That fact has led us to say time and again that the process of adjustment of domestic policies in the face of the blowout in our external difficulties is just too slow. The Treasurer may be critical of the United States of America not doing enough at present in the measures reported over the weekend. It announced that it will be introducing in the next fiscal year $30 billion worth of cuts off the deficit. The reality is that Australia is relatively worse off than the United States. The Treasurer calls on the Americans to do more but throws up the smokescreen that we cannot panic and do anything here. He is seeking, firstly, to slip into next year so that, secondly, he does not do too much on the eve of the State election of his mate Barrie Unsworth and, thirdly-the greatest smokescreen-slip into the next calendar year which means that he can raise the smokescreen of alleging to cut more off expenditure when in fact he will be cutting only off the Forward Estimates; the wish list and the bids of the departments. Instead of cutting into the programs now, he will make cuts on the Forward Estimates and claim that he has made far more significant cuts than in reality occurred. The duplicity of that act has already been seen through and we will be seeing a lot more of that down the line.

The Government has been failing the thrust of the nation on the macroeconomic front. Its vacillation on the issue of economic reform and privatisation shows it is also failing us on the microeconomic front. The third Hawke Government was to have microeconomic policies as its central feature. It was going to show the way to the world on how it would handle microeconomic policies to increase the allocative efficiency of resources and to enable Australia to respond better to international market conditions. One element of that was privatisation and there it is in a total unmitigated mess. The Left is opposing what the Prime Minister has said; the Centre Left is advocating that it cannot proceed; and elements of the Right, particularly at the trade union level, are saying that, even if Hawke goes on a frolic on his own, Labor will not privatise.

At the end of my speech I shall move the amendment I foreshadowed earlier, requesting the Government to review the question of privatising the Commonwealth Bank. I reiterate that the Opposition is considering a review to see whether it should add the Commonwealth Bank to the list of authorities to be privatised. I request that the Government give that same consideration. We will see how dinkum it is in pursuing effective privatisation programs and we will see whether it can get beyond the sale of minuscule authorities to deal with the effective ones. For the reasons that I have outlined in this address, the economic programs of this Government are increasingly seen to be a charade. Let us see whether the same applies to one particular element of them, namely privatisation. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House (a) notes the undercapitalisation of the Commonwealth Bank and the subsequent constraints this imposes on its efficient administration, (b) calls upon the Government to undertake a review to assess whether the sale of the Commonwealth Bank would be in the best interests of the Australian people'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to contribute to this debate after having listened to the born-again economist, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). It seems to me that he spent most of his time talking about the question of privatisation and in fact did not spend much time looking at the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill and the benefits of it. While some of the provisions of the Bill have attracted opposition, particularly from the insurance industry, I am confident that the general thrust of the amendments will boost the overall efficiency and competitiveness of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Some of the more important changes will confer upon the bank the ability to provide insurance services and to provide a wider range of banking and investment services, including trusts, stock broking, futures and commodity dealings. In the past the bank, because of its charter, has been unable to involve itself in this significant area of commercial activity which, following the deregulation of the financial system in recent years, has become a very profitable area of banking activity which many other banks have enjoyed for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with much interest to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition when he said that in his opinion the bank was under-capitalised. Perhaps that is so to some extent; but this has been addressed in the Bill. The amendments will give the Commonwealth Banking Corporation's Board a formal role in the determination of a dividend payment to the Commonwealth. Under the existing Act the question of the dividend payable was determined solely by the Treasurer without reference to the Board. This Bill will give the Board the ability to make a recommendation to the Treasurer as to the dividend payable, but only after having given due regard to the need for both the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia to achieve a reasonable rate of return on capital, to increase reserves, to fund expansion of activities and to meet prudential requirements. However, the Act does not take away from the Treasurer the overall power to insist on a dividend payment of up to 45 per cent of profits.

The general activities of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, which include the Commonwealth Savings Bank and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia (CDB) have for some 20 years been of special interest to me, having commenced my full time employment at age 17 with the Commonwealth Bank. For that reason I was very interested to contribute to this debate. In the past the bank has always been regarded as the people's bank and was originally established in 1912 by an early Federal Labor Government, the Fisher Government, specifically to provide a banking service that catered for the general public. Whilst with the advent of the entry of foreign banks into this country and the deregulation of the financial system it has become imperative for the bank to involve itself in the more lucrative areas of sophisticated financing, it is regrettable that the bank seems at times to be losing sight of its original charter.

One area of activity of the bank in which I have a lot of personal experience and in which the bank was heavily involved was in the provision of financial services to the migrant community. The migrant information service of the Commonwealth Bank in Brisbane was, from my personal knowledge, one of the more important areas of the banks activity in that State, and I understand also in the rest of Australia. The staffing level of that service has now been dramatically decreased. I remember that that service was so efficient that not only did it assist newly arrived migrants in matters relating to finance but also it helped them to establish themselves in the country and in the community. A very good friend of mine spoke 13 different languages and was employed by the migrant information service. He did a fantastic job in helping migrants to settle in this country. The bank's activities in this area were highly commendable and represented an active involvement in general community affairs, which I believe nowadays is sadly lacking.

I strongly urge the Board not to lose sight of the purpose for which the bank was originally established. I am sure that the amendments in this Bill will allow the bank not only to achieve greater profits by the expansion of its permitted areas of activity but also to provide that little extra to the ordinary man and women on the street which is certainly not available from other banking institutions.

It is no secret that there are strong sections of the community, indeed the Liberal Party of Australia and members of the Opposition, who would like to see the Commonwealth Banking Corporation privatised. I hope that these amendments will go a long way towards ensuring that there is no need for the Government to consider this option. In the past the Commonwealth Bank has been seen-I am sure it will be so seen in the future-as a publicly owned organisation which not only is run efficiently but also provides that little extra to the community, as it was originally intended that it should do. I for one believe that this distinguishing factor would be lost if the bank were to be privatised. For this and many other reasons I am totally against any suggestion that this public enterprise should be sold off to the private sector.

On the issue of insurance services, I cannot over-emphasise the enormous benefits available to the bank in getting involved in business opportunities that are offered in insurance. One of the more significant amendments will allow the bank to become actively involved in insurance. I completely reject what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said about the bank's becoming involved in insurance services. This is something in which the bank should be involved. Other major banks have done so and are making a lot of money out of it. Frankly, I think that the Commonwealth Bank should do exactly the same thing. I was not surprised to see in recent Press reports that the insurance industry strongly opposes this legislation. I guess it has probably lobbied the Opposition on this. The opposition of the insurance industry convinces me that this area of the Bill is one of great merit. The insurance industry can hardly complain, given the massive profits made by it on a consistent basis. One has only to visit the business districts of major capital cities to see tangible proof of these profits. Every second major building is owned by an insurance company and, without doubt, the majority of Australian insurance companies, it can be said, have a licence to print money. The insurance industry generally is so protective of its market that it is no wonder that it whinges and whines at the prospect of another competitor in the market-place. I strongly urge the bank's Board to market vigorously in this area of its expanded activity and to provide cheaper premiums wherever possible. Its existing customer base will ensure the bank's success in this new field of activity, and I am certain will strongly contribute to its profit-earning potential.

In line with my belief that these amendments will give the Commonwealth Bank the scope for higher earnings, I strongly suggest that the bank resist the temptation to introduce transaction fees. I have already publicly expressed my strong opposition to such a fee and I believe that the private banks that are contemplating the introduction of transaction fees should be condemned for their greedy and uncaring attitude towards their customers. The imposition of transaction fees could quite easily result in pensioners, fixed income earners and small depositors becoming prime targets for petty criminals. The tendency will be for these people to keep cash on hand rather than pay a fee for the pleasure of withdrawing their own money. I suggest that, by not charging such a fee, the Commonwealth Bank would attract the many thousands of small depositors who would undoubtedly leave the private banks who charge such fees.

I was most concerned to learn recently that the bank intends to reduce staffing levels by 14 per cent in the next four years. This would mean that, in an effort to improve productivity and to cut costs, up to 5,000 jobs will be lost. Whilst I am aware that no retrenchments are envisaged and that the loss would be through natural attrition, I am sure that the magnitude of the loss of these jobs would be viewed with great concern. I strongly urge the Commonwealth Bank Board to reconsider its decision in this area. These amendments allowing the bank to involve itself in expanded areas of financial activity and in the general insurance industry could well be the answer to at least part of this problem. I find it very difficult to comprehend how the Board could contemplate such drastic cuts in its work force and at the same time prepare itself for a significant increase in its sphere of business activity. Such a significant loss of jobs in any industry is a matter of great concern to the Australian work force and I earnestly hope that again the Board remembers that its original charter confers upon the bank a general obligation to operate not only efficiently and productively but also in the interests of the Australian community generally.

I understand that the major reason for the proposed cutbacks is the Board's concern that its profit for the 1986-87 year was 15 per cent lower before tax than the previous year's. In its annual report the bank itself admits that the previous year realised buoyant levels of profit. I suggest that, whilst it is natural that the Board would be desirous of continuing such high levels of profitability, there is no reason for it to be so concerned at the profit drop as to cut its work force drastically.

Before ending my contribution to this debate, I wish to make particular mention of the activities of the Commonwealth Development Bank. The Commonwealth Development Bank has a special role as a supplementary lender handling the finance of borrowers unable to obtain finance elsewhere on reasonable terms and conditions. Under its charter the bank provides finance to primary producers and small to medium size businesses for any business purpose. In some cases it may also provide equity finance. I believe, and I think this is something which may not be well known, unless people are actively involved in the bank or have some relationship with the bank as a customer or whatever, that in recent years the Commonwealth Development Bank has become extremely conservative in its lending policy. Whilst I can appreciate that the bank is no doubt sensitive in the area of the attraction of bad debts-all banks are-I remind the Commonwealth Development Bank that its charter is such that it should be taking higher risks if it means saving businesses from folding and if it means allowing a business increased capital to expand its activities and thus create further employment.

I am aware of one particular instance of a small manufacturing plant in my electorate of Bowman, which employs some 20 people, which is being prevented by the bank from expanding its activities by refusing to allow the first mortgagee, a private bank, to make further capital available to the proprietor of the plant. I understand that to ensure the viability of the business, capital is required to purchase new machinery, which would lead to greater production and the ability of the business to employ increased staff. I am told that on each occasion a proposition has been put to the first mortgagee the CDB has torpedoed the proposed budgets because it holds a second mortgage over the business and will not allow the first mortgagee appropriate priority on its first mortgage security. The owner has more than adequate security to substantiate a larger advance, but is being frustrated in his expansion plans by the Commonwealth Development Bank. I say that with much regret. I would strongly suggest that the Board conduct a review of the lending policies of the Commonwealth Development Bank with the aim of ensuring that it sticks to its original aims and objectives of assisting small to medium size businesses rather than frustrating their efforts to stay viable and to expand. Obviously I oppose the amendments. The insurance part of the Bill is probably one of the best parts. I support the general thrust of the Bill and commend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this afternoon the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill, which requires that some increased powers be given to the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, which the coalition would agree with. These increased powers are needed because of the deregulation which has taken place in recent years. This has opened up new vistas for banking and financial activities, both domestically and internationally. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), said, the Commonwealth Bank was established in 1912, and today it has a staff of about 33,000 employed full time, and 5,000 employed part time. It is interesting to go back and look at the Hansard of 15 November 1911, when the Bill to establish the bank was first brought into the House. Mr Fisher, the then Prime Minister and honourable member for Wide Bay, as he was, and also Treasurer, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This will be a bank belonging to the people, and directly managed by the people's own agents.
Later, when speaking on the intent of the Bill to set up the Commonwealth Bank, he said:
This is a business concern pure and simple, and not a matter for idealism.

When we examine this table, it leads us to think of the benefits of privatisation which the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), spoke of in his speech, because no matter what factor we look at in comparing the Commonwealth Bank with the other private banks, it would seem that the Commonwealth Bank does not perform as well as some would perhaps think. So the Commonwealth Bank was well behind there.
—What year was this?

—This was for the last financial year, 1986-87. If we look at the return on assets, we see that the Commonwealth Bank returned 0.45 per cent, whereas the other banks were substantially up on that, about 50 per cent greater. If we judge the Commonwealth Bank by the tax paid, to see what benefit it is returning, the three major private banks fare much better. For last year the Commonwealth Bank paid almost $181m in tax, but the ANZ bank paid $427m, the National Australia Bank paid almost $277m and the Westpac Bank returned almost $398m. If we look at the net profit after tax, the same sorts of proportions come up again. So there seems to be no great benefit in having the Commonwealth Bank in government hands on those factors alone.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Bank does have one advantage over the other private banks in that it has the lowest exposure to Third World debt. While the ANZ has an exposure to Third World debt of about $1.5 billion, Westpac of about half a billion dollars and the National Australia Bank has an exposure of less than a quarter of a billion dollars, the Commonwealth Bank has an exposure of only some $30m, so it does have an advantage there. Now that the Government is looking at privatising various entities, including the Commonwealth Bank, it is interesting to look at how it has somersaulted on what it has said. I refer to a quote of the Treasurer, Paul Keating, in Hansard of 23 May 1985, in which he said that the sale of the Commonwealth Bank-he goes on to list other organisations:
. . . is simply vandalism of Australia's great public authorities . . .
The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said at the Nunawading by-election campaign on 21 July 1985:

Privatisation is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia. They will transfer then into the hands of a privileged few to the cost of every one of us.
He reinforced that statement on 21 November 1985, when he said:
They know, as anyone who thinks about the issue of privatisation knows, that it would mean higher prices, higher costs, higher taxes and higher fares.

Apparently, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and others have had second thoughts. There are, of course, many reasons why we would want to privatise organisations. I believe that there are 22 different ways of doing so, but they boil down to three main methods. First, there is the sale of an asset. One may transfer the title of the asset from the public sector to the private sector. One can do this in a number of forms, either in part or in whole. One can do it by sale to a single entity, by sale to a group, or by sale to a large number, such as by selling shares in it. The Government used this method when it offloaded the Belconnen shopping mall. A second way of privatising is by contracting out various duties to the private sector, such as the cleaning of government buildings. That is a well recognised way of doing it. The third main method is by the use of vouchers that people can use for certain goods or services. This method is used in Australia with regard to health and medical benefits cards.

Government ownership and control of the Commonwealth Bank, I believe, when one studies the facts and figures of the bank, is only holding it back. The bank has to operate under some restrictions that do not apply to private banks. When one thinks about it, the Commonwealth Bank is just another bank. Why should it be owned by the Government rather than by private owners? The Commonwealth Bank, of course, has about one-third of the savings bank market and about one-fifth of trading bank business, so it is a very large bank in this country. But it appears that there is no advantage to the Government in actually owning the bank. The net return to the Federal Government over the last 10 years has been actually below zero. The Government would have been better off if it had been privately owned-if it had been run in the way in which other banks are run, and had been paying tax like the other banks.

If one looks at the bank from the point of view of earnings per employee, the Commonwealth Bank is well behind the private banks. In the financial year 1984-85, the Commonwealth Bank earned about $6,000 per year per employee, whereas Westpac and ANZ earned about $8,500 per year per employee, and the National Bank in that year earned about $12,500 per year per employee. If one looks at the figures for the Commonwealth Bank for its expenses as a proportion of net income-that is, the gross income less interest paid out-one will see that it has a higher expense regime than its competitors.
