TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. If one looks at the growth of the Commonwealth Bank in recent years, one will see that it also lags behind the three major private banks. So from whatever point of view it is examined, it does not shape up well. Of course, if the Government sold the Commonwealth Bank by whatever shape or form, it would be of interest to know what it would bring. There have been various calculations made in recent years as to what it is worth and what it would bring on the open market. Most of the valuations are between $1,500m and $2,000m. Of course, if the Government sold all of the bank in one hit-I doubt whether even the coalition would go along with that-the money could be used to pay off debt, which Prime Minister Fisher alluded to in 1911. If it did this, the Government would save more in interest payments on the debt than it would receive in dividends from the bank. The Government should ponder that very strongly. So from the point of view of benefit to people there is a very strong case to review the question of privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. On the evidence that I have spoken about today, I would be a very strong supporter of privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal briefly with a couple of clauses in the loan contracts between the Commonwealth Bank and its clients, because these contracts have disadvantaged people in my electorate. I refer both to the Commonwealth Bank as a whole and to the Commonwealth Development Bank. The first case concerns a Mr Robert Senior from Forbes, who took out a loan of $170,000 from the Commonwealth Bank to develop his property. He took out that loan some time ago, at an interest rate of 20.25 per cent. He subsequently learnt that the State Bank could offer the same loan at a rate of interest that was 3 per cent less-17 1/4 per cent. It represented saving on interest of about $5,100 per year. However, a clause in his contract read:

In the event of prepayment or partial prepayment of principle to the Bank, the Bank shall, at its option, be entitled to an early repayment fee not exceeding the equivalent of three months interest on the sum so paid.

When Mr Senior paid out that loan early, in order to transfer it to the State Bank, the Commonwealth Bank hit him with three months interest, which came to $8,500. I wrote to the bank about this. It wrote back and said that the option is exercised invariably in cases such as this one, where a term loan is being retired from finance from other institutions. In other words, if the borrower had won Lotto and paid out the loan, the three months penalty clause would not have applied, but because the loan was being transferred from one financial institute to another, the bank saw fit to apply the clause. That is quite ridiculous. This sort of clause is outdated. It was probably brought in somewhere near the beginning of this century when interest rates were only a quarter of what they are now. It also acts to eliminate competition between financial institutions. The Minister should look at modifying this clause some time in the future.

Another constituent, Mr Barry Fragar, who used to live in Trundle in my electorate, but who has since moved to Queensland, took out a loan of $300,000 from the Commonwealth Development Bank to purchase a property, but because of drought, high interest rates and other difficulties, he was forced to sell his property. He gave the Commonwealth Development Bank seven weeks notice that he would pay out the loan. Again, this three-month penalty clause was applied and he had to shell out $13,500 which, I believe, is quite outrageous. It is high time that this anomaly was modified. In conclusion, the coalition supports this Bill. In particular we support the amendment to the motion for the second reading that the shadow Treasurer has moved. We hope that the Government will support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill, which is before the House, will help to place the Commonwealth Bank on a firmer commercial footing. The measures contained in the Bill are in keeping with the Government's actions in 1984. The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Act 1984 was formulated with a view to improving the administrative and financial structure of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, enabling the constituent banks to better compete with other banking and non-banking institutions. It is also in keeping with the actions of the Whitlam Labor Government. In 1974 that Government extended the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank, allowing it for the first time to provide finance for tourist development projects. Placing this great Australian institution on a more commercial footing similar to that of its private competitors and encouraging it to compete is a sensible objective, particularly in view of the fact that the economy, and especially the banking system, has been deregulated to a greater extent than at any other time in its history.

SPEECH.PARA: While enhancing competitiveness, and indeed encouraging competition, we should not overlook the great differences between the Commonwealth Bank and the private banks. In many ways it is not appropriate to compare the performance of the Commonwealth Bank with that of its private competitors. This is an error that is often made by those who look at the bank as a potential subject of privatisation. The debate about the future of the bank has tended to revolve around the so-called funding crisis of the bank. The main argument of the advocates of privatisation is that the bank needs a capital injection-figures ranging from $200m to $500m have been suggested in the Press-and that a share issue is the only appropriate means of raising this sum. In the second reading stage speech on the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill in May 1984, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) mooted the possibility of a 20 per cent share issue.

My concern is that the debate has unfolded as if this were the only way to broaden the bank's capital base. However, there are alternatives to a share issue on some percentage of the bank. These alternatives are not getting as much coverage in the public debate as they should. As a first option the Government could forgo its dividend. As a second option the Government could waive some or all of the bank's taxation obligations. In 1986-87 the taxation revenue from the bank was $181m. A third option is that the bank could issue an appropriately designed subordinated debt. In the United Kingdom the Government permits public authorities-those that are left-to make up one-third of their capital base in this way. It is interesting to note that Westpac Banking Corporation has raised over $2 billion in subordinated debt. Though I acknowledge that not all Westpac's new capital of this kind has been used to meet that authority's prudential requirements, it has been used to fund expansion and, in Westpac's case, overseas expansion. On that note, I will read the following comment from the Reserve Bank of Australia's report and financial statements of 30 June 1987 when dealing with the arrangement that it made with the trading banks back in September 1986 that it increased its minimum capital ratios to the vicinity of 6 per cent of total assets. It commented that some of the banks had moved to meet the requirement by way of increasing shareholder funds, but also that they had used other means. I quote:
Several banks raised substantial amounts of foreign currency subordinated perpetual debt in acceptable form.

But this is a form of fund raising that the Commonwealth Bank has chosen not to pursue. A final option is for the Government to increase its paid up capital in the bank, not funded directly from the Budget, but by the issue of a special long term bond. Privatisation is far from the only alternative.

It is also relevant to examine in more detail the so-called funding crisis that faces the bank. It is alleged that the bank requires a capital injection in large part to meet the Government's stricter prudential requirement-that is, a fixed ratio between a bank's assets and its capital. There are a number of points that should be made which take account of the vast differences between the Commonwealth Bank and its private competitors. Firstly, the rationale for requiring the Commonwealth Bank to meet the Reserve Bank's strict prudential guidelines is dubious. Prudential requirements are imposed on banks to ensure that deposits are safe. The capital base acts as a cushion to absorb losses arising from unforeseen circumstances. The imposition of these requirements also acts to assure depositors in a private bank of the willingness of shareholders to back the bank.

In relation to private banks, prudential requirements are logical and sensible as the ownership of private banks is diverse and, to a large extent, grouped in nominee companies. However, the Australian people, through their Government, own and stand behind the Commonwealth Bank. I remind the House that Labor Prime Minister Andrew Fisher, who has already been quoted by Opposition members in this debate, in his second reading speech on the establishment of the Commonwealth Bank in November 1911, stated that it was to be:
. . . a bank belonging to the people, and directly managed by the people's own agents.

Surely there can be no greater assurance of its viability. Nevertheless, even if prudential requirements continue to be imposed on the Commonwealth Bank, some account must surely be taken of the government guarantees that back the institution. At present, zero value is placed on the government backing of the bank when calculating its various capital requirements.

Consideration should also be given to varying capital requirements according to the level of risk involved in the bank's assets and activities. The Commonwealth Bank is a low risk institution. It focuses mainly on the domestic market, a situation which would suggest that its prudential capital requirements should be relatively lower. It is interesting to note in the Reserve Bank's annual report the following comment dealing with the prudential requirement of different banks:

The current approach to capital adequacy relates capital to total assets. This does not take account of differences in risk attaching to various classes of assets in a bank's portfolio nor of the risks associated with its off-balance-sheet transactions. There is growing support among supervisors in other countries for a `risk ratio' approach to the measurement of capital adequacy. This assigns risk weightings to the various categories of assets and off-balance-sheet business and then relates the aggregate assessed risk of the bank to its capital. The Bank-
that is the Reserve Bank-
is holding discussion with banks on technical aspects of moving to a `risk ratio' approach.

I contend that a risk ratio approach would better serve the needs of the Commonwealth Bank. According to the advocates of privatisation, if the bank does not receive the necessary injection of capital, not only will it fail to grow, it will wither on the vine, forcing a massive scaling down of operations. Like many of the pro- privatisation arguments, this consists of the hot air of a public relations campaign rather than a rational approach to the issues. On the one hand, the Commonwealth Bank's needs for funds for capital investment are modest. As I have said, the so-called funding crisis stems largely from the need to meet stricter prudential requirements. On the other hand, when we consider what is most likely to result in any reduction in the level of service, privatisation-either in full or part-is surely not the solution but the greatest threat. With private shareholders, even as a minority, the bank would be forced to increase its profit distribution simply as a means of making the shares attractive. It is not difficult to imagine a situation where each aspect of the bank's operations would need to justify its existence by returning a prescribed level of profits. I suggest that it is under such circumstances that services will be lost to the public.

Let us be reminded of what services we are talking about. The Commonwealth Bank has the largest share of personal accounts. It is the largest institutional lender for housing with loans totalling more than $7 billion. It has the largest branch network, some 1,300 branches and 500 automatic tellers, including an extensive coverage of country and remote areas. The bank is used extensively by pensioners and other low income groups. It provides a free cashing service for pensioners and social security recipients. Seventy per cent of social security recipients bank with the Commonwealth. It provides a migrant information service, although I note the comments of the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) about the way that this service is being wound down. I hope that the Commonwealth Banking Corporation will note my colleague's suggestion.

The bank is Australia's largest lender to local councils, semi-government authorities, public corporations and boards, and non-profit organisations such as schools and churches on terms more generous than other banks. We should also note the role of the Commonwealth Development Bank and its great assistance to small business and the farming sector. I quote from a letter that I believe was sent to all honourable members from the Chief General Manager of the Commonwealth Development Bank, Mr J. W. Fletcher:

The rapid growth of the CDB's business in recent years demonstrates, I believe, the need for our special role supplementing the more usual sources of finance. Without access to finance on reasonable terms, many of our customers, major generators of employment, would have found it impossible to grow and prosper.

Privatisation in any form presents a grave threat to these and other services by which the `people's bank' fulfils its social obligation. Partial privatisation, corporatisation, commercialisation, capitalisation, or whatever one wants to call it, is, for all intents and purposes, the same as a total sell off.

In conclusion, I would like to return to the comments of the Leader of the Opposition on the occasion of his speech in the second reading debate on the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill in 1984. In connection with his proposal to sell off 20 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank he stated that the sale would be `not to dreaded multi-national companies, not even to large Australian companies, but to ordinary Australian shareholders'. This is a classic piece of Thatcherism-people's capitalism, the shareholding masses. Of course, in Australia we have the benefit of examining the British experience of people's capitalism and we know it to be a sham and a fraud. I take British Telecom as an example. Amidst all the rhetoric and hyperbole about people's capitalism, the sobering reality is that institutional and large investors now hold 86 per cent of British Telecom shares. Small shareholders, that is those with fewer than 800 shares, constitute only 14 per cent. Of this 14 per cent, employees now hold only 2 per cent. Already, as was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 August, some of Australia's best known big businesses-Larry Adler's consortiums and Kerry Packer's Australian Consolidated Press-have indicated that they would be in the bidding if the bank were to go on the auction block. People's capitalism is a myth behind which the Thatcher Government has flogged off public enterprises to big business. There is no reason to assume that the same would not occur here.

This Bill will enhance the bank's competitiveness. It will lead to the bank's providing a more efficient and innovative banking service to the Australian community. That is not to say that in different ways the bank has not tried to contend with becoming a more efficient organisation. I briefly give as an example the agreement that the Corporation has come to with the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association about the second tier wage agreement. The bank has come up with a quite innovative form of package. Of the second tier wage increase, 3 per cent will be an across the board increase and one per cent will be paid into a performance pool. This performance pool will be distributed on a performance basis, as shown in the usual annual assessment of staff. This is a recognition that the Corporation must deal with its resources in a more efficient way. The first Labor Government with a majority in both Houses-the Fisher Government-established the Commonwealth Bank as the people's bank. In the people's hands it should remain. I have pleasure in supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As other speakers in this debate have pointed out, the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill extends the functions of the Commonwealth Banks following the review by the Treasury and the Commonwealth Banks themselves into the operation of those banks. The legislation is designed to improve the efficiency of the Commonwealth Banks and to define more precisely the relationship between them and the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of points I would like to make in relation to the extension of the functions of the Commonwealth Banks which falls under the heading of improved efficiency. First of all I note-this is a point that has been made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer (Mr Peacock)-that the legislation provides for a wider range of insurance services offered by the Commonwealth Bank. That is being done so that the Commonwealth Bank can compete more effectively with other banks which provide that wider range of insurance services. I have a very real concern that if this wider range of insurance services is to be taken too far by the Commonwealth Bank we could end up by having yet another government insurance office at the Federal level. I think most members of this House would be well aware of the reservations I and many other people in the community have about the role of government insurance commissions and the way those bodies have been used and manipulated for purposes other than to provide effective insurance services.

There is no suggestion in this legislation, as it stands, that the Commonwealth Bank is intending to move down that particularly dangerous path. But I warn honourable members that theoretically that could happen under this legislation and that is one reason why the suggestion of the shadow Treasurer that we should restrict fairly carefully the insurance functions of the Commonwealth Bank should be supported by both sides of this House. There is also a concern-as has happened with the State government insurance commissions-that there could be a substantial blowout in borrowings by those particular financial instrumentalities. Again, we would not like to see that at the Federal level. I certainly agree very strongly with the proposition that the insurance functions of the Commonwealth Bank should be restricted precisely to being ancillary to the banking services that the Commonwealth Bank provides.

The second point I make in relation to the new and extended functions of the Commonwealth Bank is that they are being extended quite broadly to trusts, stockbroking, the futures market, commodity dealings and so on. Of course, the argument is very strongly put forward that this is necessary if the Commonwealth Bank is to provide the sorts of services provided by other banks, such as the National Australia Bank Ltd or Westpac Banking Corporation, and compete with them. That is perfectly comprehensible. I can understand the concerns of the Commonwealth Bank in not being able to provide the same services as other banks and therefore not being able to compete properly. The difficulty here is that we are ending up with a nationalised bank-a government owned bank-which is extending itself into areas such as stockbroking, the futures market and commodity dealings.

In my own State of South Australia the State Bank of South Australia has now bought 50 per cent of a real estate company, Myles Pearce and Co. Pty Ltd. This means that the largest real estate company in that State is effectively owned by the Government. Most members of this House will agree that we very strongly support the private sector of the economy. Healthy private sector competition is a view that has been widely held in recent years on both sides of this House. When we see the increasing and growing role of State banks and the Commonwealth Bank in areas which are the traditional preserve of the private sector, that is something to be wary of. We are left in a difficult situation because if we actually oppose this legislation and the proposition that the Commonwealth Bank should extend its services into those areas, we are saying that the Commonwealth Bank should not be able to compete effectively. It is only reasonable to suggest that that argument does not make an awful lot of sense. The Commonwealth Bank has to be able to compete and compete effectively. I do not think anyone wants to inhibit it from competing.

The next question that this legislation raises is whether it is really saying that we should move towards private ownership of the Commonwealth Bank, rather than it being owned by the Government. When addressing that issue one has to ask what justifications there are in the first place for having a government-owned bank or series of banks, as we have in Australia. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that in countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States, such banks do not exist, whereas for many years we have had a government owned bank at the Federal level and a whole series of government-owned banks at the State level.

Let us look at the role of a government bank. The first role is as a central bank. As far as I know, all countries' central banks are understandably owned by their governments. I think the last privately owned central bank was the Bank of England which was nationalised, from recollection, in 1944. That is quite a long time ago. If the Commonwealth Bank were still the central bank there would be a strong argument for retaining it in public ownership but it is not and it has not been since 1959.

The second argument in favour of a government bank is the argument the Fisher Government used when it created the Commonwealth Bank; it was reiterated by the Liberal Government in 1959. It was argued that a government owned bank would provide more effective competition in a market which had insufficient competition. There was something to be said for that argument. Nowadays, when we have more domestic banks than we had in 1959, or than we had 10 years ago-16 foreign banks now operate in Australia-nobody who knows anything about banking, and most people know something about it, would deny that there is very strong competition at last in the Australian market. So the argument that we need a publicly owned bank to provide competition no longer carries any substance.

The third argument is perhaps the most important argument. Does a publicly owned bank provide some sort of social function? To be specific, does the Commonwealth Bank provide some sort of social function? The Commonwealth Bank has more branches than any other bank, so it could be argued that by having a very extensive branch network it is thereby providing some sort of social function. But the other major private banks, such as Westpac and the National Australia Bank, also have extremely extensive branch networks. Westpac, for example, has just under 1,000 branches. The Commonwealth Bank has just under 1,300 branches. So the argument that because the Commonwealth Bank has more branches it thereby provides a more effective branch network than any other bank has some justification, but it is an extremely marginal justification. If we were to make the Commonwealth Bank compete more effectively in the market-place-it claims that it does anyway-and if that were to lead to the closure of some of its branches it would still not lead to major social dislocation.

Another aspect of the social function would be to ask whether it is providing loans to people which the general banking system does not provide. That was originally the case. It certainly is not the case any longer. It provides a higher proportion of savings bank loans than any other bank, but that is an historical accident. It does so because of its history. However, it charges the same interest rates as other banks on housing loans. Access to those loans and to other banking services is no different from access to the other private banks. So it does not seem that in that area it is providing any kind of social function.

There is the argument that because the Commonwealth Bank is a government owned bank it will provide greater security for people who have savings with the bank. When one asks people whether they are in favour of the sale of the Commonwealth Bank to the private sector, and they say that they are not, and one asks why they are not, the reason often given is their concern about their savings. The implication is that one's savings are less safe with Westpac or the National Australia Bank. I am sorry to keep using those two examples; I am not really doing any advertising for these two banks, Mr Deputy Speaker. I will choose some other examples when they come to mind. Their advertising is obviously more effective because their names are more strongly in my mind. Those two banks provide great security for people who have their savings with them, as does the Commonwealth Bank. All the major banks-the Commonwealth Bank, but particularly the major private sector banks-are very strongly protected by the Reserve Bank of Australia. There is no question that the Reserve Bank-it cannot, anyway-would simply turn its back on the major Australian banks if they were to run into difficulty. So the argument that the Commonwealth Bank, because it is publicly owned, is performing some major social function does not have a great deal of substance.

A fourth argument was used during the South Australian State election in the context of the possible privatisation of the State Bank of South Australia. The argument is that the Commonwealth Bank provides revenue for the Government and that, if it were to be sold, the Government would lose that revenue base. Mr Deputy Speaker, let me remind you, in case you are being lured by that argument, that in 1985 the Federal Government received more money in income tax from the three major banks than it received in revenue from the Commonwealth Bank. So that argument is not sustainable. If the Commonwealth Bank were to be owned by the private sector-I will explain why in a second-it would have some competitive advantages that it does not have at the moment and would generate significantly increased revenue, not just for itself in the form of profits but also in taxation revenue for the Government.

Because the Commonwealth Bank is publicly owned it suffers from a series of competitive disadvantages. The reason for the 1984 legislation and for this legislation is to try to help overcome some of those competitive disadvantages. That is why, on balance, I welcome this legislation. There is evidence in the profit performance of the Commonwealth Bank that it has been hindered by its competitive disadvantages. The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) went through many of the figures. Of all the major banks, the Commonwealth Bank historically has had the lowest levels of return on both assets and equity. It has the lowest level of earnings per employee. In 1984-85, quite dramatically, the Commonwealth Bank's earnings per employee were only about half of those of the National Australia Bank. That is a very substantial profit performance differential.

It is argued by some that the Commonwealth Bank, to put it in a pejorative sense, is a consistently poor performer. I would say not that it is a poor performer but that it is a performer which has not been as effective as the private banks. I will run through a handful of examples of why the Commonwealth Bank is disadvantaged because it is owned by the public sector. Firstly, decisions on important matters, such as operating off-shore, have to be referred first to the Treasurer. So political considerations are brought into play. There has been a reluctance by the Commonwealth Bank to operate off-shore because of political considerations. The new Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank recently said:
If we didn't have this restraint-
that is, the suggestion that the bank should not operate too extensively off-shore-
we may well have decided to become a world bank.

That quotation is important. Most banks are now moving into the global economy, the global market. If the Commonwealth Bank gets left behind it will not have the same opportunities to maximise its profitability.

Secondly, the Commonwealth Bank is hindered by having to pay and adhere to public sector salary and wage guidelines. The bank has introduced greater flexibility in recent years at the lower level of its hierarchy but at the top level it still cannot pay comparative wage or salary rates for management paid by the private sector. Some figures have been given to me in the last few hours which I have not been able to check. I understand that the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank earns about $95,000 a year, whereas his private sector counterpart earns about $250,000. I could stand corrected on those figures but they illustrate the basic disadvantage which the Commonwealth Bank suffers.

Thirdly, from time to time the Commonwealth Bank is subject to political interference. In the context of operating off-shore I have made it clear that that is one way political interference can put the bank at a disadvantage. The appointment of the new Managing Director some time ago created turmoil within the bank, another minor example of the effect of political interference on the performance of the bank. Another example is that when industrial disputes break out in the bank they cannot be unilaterally settled by the bank. They have to be referred to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Again that puts the bank at a disadvantage-in that instance, I would argue, a very great disadvantage.

Fourthly, theoretically it is an advantage that the Commonwealth provides de facto guarantees for the Commonwealth Bank, but when the Commonwealth's credit rating is continually being downgraded, as it has in the last couple of years, that advantage turns quickly to a disadvantage for the Commonwealth Bank. Finally-this is the key to the whole argument of privatisation-the capital base of the Commonwealth Bank is too small. This point was made by the previous Managing Director, Vern Christie, and is repeatedly made in the public debate now. It is argued that the bank needs an injection of up to $500m of additional capital. Where will it be able to get that money from? If it does not get that money, it will not be able, under prudential requirements, to expand its deposits and that will again put it at a competitive disadvantage. As the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) mentioned, the Reserve Bank of Australia is now demanding an improved capital to assets ratio. Again, for as long as its capital is restricted, the Commonwealth Bank will not be able to compete in the way the other banks can.

The Commonwealth Bank could raise extra capital by retaining profits and having greater flexibility in its dividend payment, and this legislation will help it to do that. But it is unlikely to be able to raise sufficient funds from that source. It could raise money through an injection simply from the Treasury-from general revenue-but to ask for $500m in the present climate, I suspect, would be more than ambitious. The honourable member for Scullin suggested that it could extend its indebtedness: the Commonwealth could issue special bonds, for example, for the Commonwealth Bank; it could operate a system of subordinated debt and so on. I suppose one cannot ignore that suggestion but we have to ask why we are always talking about increasing indebtedness. Are not there better ways of improving the capital base than extending the debt either of the Commonwealth or of the Commonwealth Bank, thereby raising prudential issues?

I suppose the Commonwealth Bank could raise additional capital by stripping some of its assets, by selling off its investments in merchant banks, financial authorities, travel, and so on, but I would not support that. That would be counter to the spirit of this legislation which is for the bank to be able to provide a whole range, rather than a very limited range of banking services. If it were to make those sales it would not be able to provide the extensive services that it provides and, therefore, it would not be so competitive. So I do not think that that is much of an option. This leaves us with the one substantial option-the one which Senator Gareth Evans clearly supports and which obviously some honourable members on the other side of the House support, although I understand they are in the minority-and that is for the private sector to be able to invest in equity in the Commonwealth Bank, call it privatisation if you like.

The Opposition has said that it will review its policy on the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. I more than support that move. I believe that privatisation will be the best option, the best solution, to the future of the Commonwealth Bank. Any opposition to that measure is not practical opposition; opposition to that is based on a notion, an ideology. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) keeps saying, we need an intelligent debate on these matters, not a debate which is consummated by ideological considerations.

The Government might consider going down the Bank of New Zealand track and allowing, I think, 13 per cent of private sector investment in that bank. It may allow more than 13 per cent; it may allow 49 per cent or whatever, or it may go the whole way. The Government has to be intelligent and serious about examining those options if it is to be fair dinkum about making the Commonwealth Bank a genuinely competitive bank. At the moment it is hamstrung in the way I have described and if the Government does not take action in the future, the bank will wither while others prosper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to amend the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 and as such it represents the implementation, with regard to both the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and its member banks, of the Government's policy on Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises. The provisions in the Commonwealth Banks Amendment 1987 and the major amendments made to the Act in 1984 are in line with the general overhaul of Commonwealth public sector administration in fulfilment of a commitment undertaken by the Hawke Labor Government in its 1983 statement on Labor and quality of government.

SPEECH.PARA: The main provisions of the Bill are sixfold. First, the Bill seeks to expand the charter of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Savings Bank to enable them both to provide insurance services where, in the opinion of the Board, this is necessary for the bank to remain competitive with other banks. Secondly, it proposes to expand the powers of the Commonwealth Bank and the Savings Bank to include a wider range of banking and investment services. Thirdly, it requires the Board of the Corporation to prepare and to submit to the Treasurer a corporate plan stating the objectives of the Commonwealth banks and outlining the policies and strategies to be pursued in achieving those objectives. All of those objectives of this legislation are, I believe, laudable. Fourthly, the legislation seeks to provide the Board of the Corporation with a formal role in the determination of dividend payments by the Commonwealth banks. Fifthly, it proposes to introduce a dividend requirement for the Commonwealth Development Bank. Finally, it proposes to give the Corporation greater flexibility in staff management.

The Bill and the contributions made in the debate this afternoon give rise to the opportunity to make some comments on the Government's policy with regard to Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises. The Bill also gives us the opportunity to consider, particularly, implementation of the Government's policy in the case of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, through this legislation. The aim of the Government's policy with regard to statutory authorities and government business enterprises is to provide incentive, to enhance efficiency and to improve public accountability. Those are three very important points that we must not lose sight of. This Government, in endeavouring to seek to achieve those three aims, is committed to ensuring that public enterprises operate in that way. It is intended that these objectives be achieved through a package which combines removal of unnecessary central controls which detract from enterprise performance, with greater emphasis on bottom line performance.

It surprises me that the contributions of honourable gentlemen opposite this afternoon sought to draw attention to the fact that they do not understand, or they fail to see, how publicly owned and operated enterprises can be as efficient as privately run enterprises. I fail to see just why that should be the case. I am not blinded by some philosophical dilemma or some position of faith which has been adopted within the ranks of the Australian Labor Party. It is my view that in this Government review that will take place within the realms of the Labor Party over the next few months on this whole question of publicly owned and operated enterprises the Party will decide; we will decide what we consider to be best and we will act accordingly. I do not believe that we will be pressured by any particular group within the general community to arrive at those decisions.

Government attention, as far as this Bill is concerned will be focused on strategic issues which are properly a matter for ministerial responsibility. That comment, which pertains to the Commonwealth Bank, applies equally to a broad range of public enterprises. Therefore, we see in the provisions of this Bill an attempt to implement streamlined, performance-oriented, management practices based on devolution of responsibility with appropriate accountability for results.

The provisions also demonstrate the Government's commitment to achieving the highest levels of operational and financial efficiency in the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and its member banks. This commitment is derived from the belief that these banks are part of a group of business enterprises which constitute an important business sector providing a significant proportion of the infrastructure on which the rest of the Australian economy depends. That is a very important point. It goes to the point that was raised by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) in his contribution: the Commonwealth Bank is part of that major infrastructure on which the rest of the Australian economy depends.

There are a number of other reasons prompting the Government to seek greater efficiency and performance from these banks. First of all, through the Government all Australians have a significant investment in these enterprises. The Government needs to ensure that this investment earns an adequate rate of return. I suspect that this is one of the key factors in this debate, and it will loom as a key factor in this debate, on the question of public versus private ownership of enterprises currently in public ownership. Concomitant to this the Government is committed to maximising the public benefit by efficient operation of these enterprises. Furthermore, the degree to which efficiency can be enhanced has a major bearing on the success of the Government's program to improve Australia's international competitiveness. This is the key to the living standards of all Australians. In line with Government policy the Bill provides for a strategic corporate plan to be advanced and for financial targets to be set.

The Government will be closely monitoring the implementation of policy, not only in regard to this Bill but in regard to all Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises. While some fine tuning may be necessary, the Government believes that this policy provides a suitable, coherent, consistent and flexible approach to the oversight of authorities and enterprises. In fact, this is a view which is shared by the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank, Mr Don Sanders. On 27 October he said:

The capacity to offer a more extensive range of banking, financial, insurance and investment services will enable the bank to cater for virtually all the financial requirements of our many customers . . . Planning is well advanced for a range of insurance services to be launched in 1988, and details of these will be announced at the appropriate time.

So clearly the Commonwealth Bank is looking to the future. It is looking to the implementation of Government policy and providing a range of services which will enable it to remain competitive amongst all those privately owned banks. Mr Sanders also went on to welcome the greater autonomy and flexibility the bank was to have in managing its staff as a result of the removal from the Act of various detailed provisions governing procedures for appointment, promotion and discipline. He stated that adaptations and developments would proceed with the consultative process built up over many years with the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association. Again, that is a policy which this Government fully supports. Confrontation is out; consultation is in. Despite recent media reports that the bank is to sack 5,000 workers, I believe that this figure is greatly inflated and that only some 1,000 jobs have been targeted for rationalisation-all of which will be achieved through natural attrition.

Given that the Commonwealth Banking Corporation experienced a 15 per cent decline in before tax profit in the 1986-87 financial year, reflecting the competition from both new and established players in the now deregulated financial system, I am sure that any rational person would agree that the Bill before the House, designed to increase the competitiveness of the corporation, is in the best interests of the Australian people.

I conclude by saying that it is my view that the amendment that has been moved by the shadow Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) is really nothing but an opportunity to take advantage of what he might perceive as some divisions within the Government ranks on this whole question of public ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reckon there are.

—Let me assure the honourable gentleman that no such divisions exist, as is usual within the Government. I think he will be saved from further embarrassment on this issue following the Caucus meeting tomorrow. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their contributions to this debate. Basically the argument developed by members of the Opposition centred largely on an amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). In a sense, this amendment gave him the opportunity to address the House on the broader issues of privatisation and express the views and philosophy of the Opposition on that matter. That is a legitimate exercise within the framework of parliamentary debate. But I can only say to the honourable gentleman that he will be well aware of the fact that the Government is considering all aspects of the range of arguments that are being put forward in respect of that matter. The one thing we will not do is allow our positions, as they develop in respect of any of those matters, to be pre-empted by the Opposition in terms of any arguments that come forward. I know that the shadow Treasurer would regard that as an equally legitimate position for the Government to adopt.

SPEECH.PARA: I would remind the shadow Treasurer that, in introducing these amendments to the Act, the Government is mindful of the need to ensure that the corporation group maintains a sufficient level of capital to support the further development of its operations. One source of capital for the Commonwealth banks is retained earnings. In this regard the amendments to the Act introduce new arrangements for the determination of dividend payments which will enable the board to make a formal recommendation to the Treasurer on the level of dividend. The Treasurer will be able to accept the recommendation or, where the dividend proposed is less than 45 per cent of the amount available for distributing, vary the dividend payment up to a maximum of 45 per cent of net profits. This will ensure that at least 55 per cent of the profits of the Commonwealth Bank are retained, and allows for an even greater proportion of profits to be retained where this is considered appropriate.

These amendments will serve to promote the more efficient conduct of the operations of the corporation and its member banks to improve the profitability of the corporation group. Increased profitability of the Commonwealth banks will, of course, enable them, to improve their capital position through a higher level of retained earnings. The flexible dividend arrangement will also mean that the banks can pay a dividend lower than the statutory maximum of 45 per cent where this is considered appropriate. The Government is aware of the need to ensure that the Commonwealth banks are adequately capitalised and will keep under review whether there is a need for additional measures to supplement the above arrangements.

The other aspect, which was dwelt on for some time by members of the Opposition, went to the insurance arrangements which were proposed in the Government's amendments. The Opposition proposed a series of amendments in this regard which the Government cannot accept. The Government was perfectly aware of the insurance industry's concerns in respect of the legislation and the amendments proposed giving the Commonwealth banks a greater capacity for competitiveness in the open market. The arrangements to apply extend to the bank's insurance operations, so that it will be able to compete on an equal footing with private insurers. The Opposition's amendments, as proposed by the shadow Treasurer, seem aimed at producing precisely the same result, but they may well result inadvertently in the bank's finding itself at a competitive disadvantage. For those reasons the Government will not accept those amendments.

I foreshadow to the House an amendment which I propose to move in respect of clause 27 at the committee stage. The effect of this clause is to require the corporation to adopt proceedings in making appointments, promotions or transfers which preclude patronage and favouritism. However, the clause, as it was originally worded, would have required formal applications to be submitted for all promotions and transfers in the corporation. This is at variance with existing staffing arrangements whereby officers may be considered for promotion or transfer without necessarily having to submit formal applications, and the clause would have made staffing procedures in the corporation more unwieldy. The proposed amendment to the Bill will avoid the need for the corporation to seek formal applications for all promotions and transfers. However, it will not affect the requirement for the corporation to adopt procedures which preclude favouritism and patronage in approving promotions or transfers.

I will present an explanatory memorandum on this amendment, but I foreshadow it now. I understand that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has already been provided with a copy, but I felt it appropriate to put the House on notice and move the amendment formally later so that any honourable member who wants to address himself to this issue will not be at any disadvantage.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 is very important. The Opposition recognises the importance, and I think all members of the Australian community also recognise the importance, of aged care. We have no argument with the Government's policy direction. We think that direction is correct. We have a major argument with the implementation of the policy. Our major concern is the absolute lack of consultation between the Department of Community Services and Health and the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it is entirely appropriate to describe the Department's approach to this legislation as autocratic. That is not my word; it is the word used frequently by the industry, both by the private sector and by the voluntary aged care sector. It concerns me that the Department has developed a tendency towards autocracy, not only in terms of aged care but also in terms of child care. The capacity of the Department to conduct meaningful consultation seems to be almost non-existent. Later in my remarks I will address the industry's concerns about this particular issue.

What concerns me is the increasing politicisation of the approach of the Department of Community Services and Health to issues that it deals with. We have seen it at the forefront of the debate over public child care and we see it using the Government's policy on aged care for political purposes. During the last Federal election campaign the Department of Community Services and Health placed advertisements in Victorian newspapers. The ads said:

The nursing homes scandal is over. A fair deal for nursing home residents. Some greedy nursing home operators claim recent government changes will disadvantage residents. This is not true. The changes will provide a better deal.

I remind the House that Victoria, the same State in which these advertisements were placed, has just had a crisis in nursing homes. The confidence of the residents of those homes, their families and the community at large has been destroyed as a result of government policy which the Government was busy trumpeting at taxpayers' expense before the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be interesting to hear what they say.

—The Minister is busy shaking his head. I hope he sits in the House to listen to the rest of the remarks I intend to make today. I will quote to you what the industry thinks of the Government's policy and I will tell you what the Government is doing to the residents of nursing homes.
—Order! The Minister might contain himself and the honourable member might address his remarks through the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was provoked. As I said, the industry is particularly concerned at the way the Department is conducting the Government's policy. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is not in the House at present, has a tendency to create the impression that nursing homes are being exploited by private entrepreneurs who are making money out of the frail aged in our community and the taxpayer through Government subsidies. Let me quote from the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations (AAVCA). The associations are not private entrepreneurs. They are voluntary groups. They are church organisations and charitable organisations. They are extremely concerned at the way the Government is going about the implementation of its policy. The president of this organisation, Reverend Don Stewart, has written to the Secretary of the Department expressing those reservations. He refers to `consultations' in his correspondence in inverted commas because he does not regard them as meaningful consultations. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Department that-the Australian Nursing Homes Association aside-consultations with other consumer representatives-the ACTU (representing the nurses) and other groups-should not be allowed to distort reality. The reality is that unless there are healthy and flourishing care provider organisations then words, policies, pontifications and pious hopes for better care are just so much rhetoric.

He goes on to discuss the issues. He supports the remark that I made earlier that residents' confidence in the system is being impaired by the Government's implementation of its policy. He goes on to address a number of problems that are currently the subject of much debate within the industry and increasing public debate about resident classifications and the needs of communities. He goes on to say that the Department is unrealistic in its provisions for crisis respite care. In terms of exempt beds the proposal as outlined is not acceptable and is unlikely to attract participation by AAVCA member organisations, not the private organisations but the community based charitable church organisations. On consultation with this organisation he said:

We believe that we have much expertise to offer the Department in the formulation of policy and programs, but if our only involvement is to criticise the Department's proposals when they are prepared we feel this is an inadequate approach. A far better use of AAVCA expertise can be obtained by our involvement and consultation in the formulation of policy and program proposals. That is not possible with the present procedures. However, I must point out that the failure of the Department to advise us of the introduction of the legislation-
the legislation we are debating in the House today-
and the nature of the legislation has left us with feelings of uncertainty for the future.

That is the President of the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations speaking. Similar attitudes have been expressed by State organisations. An urgent telegram from the Executive Director of the New South Wales Branch of the Voluntary Care Association says:

The Association finds it unbelievable that during eight hours of discussion the legislation issue was not mentioned. The fact that no contact was made with the AAVCA Executive on the Friday after the discussions questions both the integrity and the sincerity of departmental officers.

It goes on to make reference to the utter disdain that officers obviously have for the industry. It makes the point that there has been a major submission made to the Government, some 23 pages, with vast numbers of questions, to which to date it has received no response. Again it is important to recognise the depth of criticism and the depth of concern in the industry over this matter. As I said, and I must stress this again, it is not the private operators, it is the voluntary operators, the people who keep vast numbers of elderly Australians in some degree of security in their latter years, that are concerned. To give honourable members some idea of the range of this concern, the Voluntary Care Association of South Australia-again a voluntary organisation, which has 110 affiliated organisations, approximately 13,000 aged tenants and about 10,000 staff-is also very critical of the Department. It refers to the Department's seemingly autocratic attitude. The association criticises the Department's method of approach, the lack of time to consider the issues and the number of documents that have been compiled by Federal and State public servants. It says in its correspondence:

Much of the documentation received from Canberra leaves the impression that the initiators have little or no practical experience with, or awareness of, the real issues relating to `Aged Accommodation and Health Care'. While they are prepared to listen to those who are best qualified to contribute, they appear to take little notice of what is said. In terms, such as `quality of life', et cetera, are used in departmental documentation, whereas the real issues are about money, theory and control, that is, the Government's and the bureaucracy's diminishing financial input over time, together with the desire for total control through regulation and funding with increasing strings attached.
The views of this organisation are summed up in the following terms:

It is surely in the best interests of Australian governments to ensure that non-profit organisations, providing quality accommodation and care services, especially those caring for the frail aged in nursing homes and hostels, remain viable. Conversely, there is certainly no mileage for any government if that does not. If the Department is really genuine in its belief that the proposals contained in its documents are realistic, then it will demonstrate its conviction and accountability by unreservedly guaranteeing to reimburse Aged Care organisations for any financial losses sustained as result of its recommendations and subsequent regulations.

We are not talking about a private entrepreneur; we are not talking about a nursing home operator that needs to make a profit. We are talking about nursing home operators who are charitable organisations, voluntary care associations. They are not interested in profit, they are just interested in maintaining the viability of their operations, and they are concerned at the impact of the legislation that the Government proposes to bring down. It is for that reason that we will propose a second reading amendment. We will also be moving certain committee stage amendments to this Bill. We will also propose, to ensure that the industry has an opportunity for meaningful consultation, that this entire Bill be referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, to give the Committee, with its representatives from both sides of this chamber, the industry and the public of Australia-because the interest of the public in this issue is very widespread-an opportunity to see what the detail of the Government's policy on aged care is and how the implementation of that policy will affect elderly Australians and those people contemplating their retirement years.

I have received vast amounts of correspondence from other sections of the industry. I will not delay the House unduly by quoting extensively from the correspondence, but the tenor of all this correspondence is exactly the same. I have not quoted from the private sector, but it is appropriate to ensure that its views on this legislation are also recorded for the benefit of the Minister. Its opening remarks begin:
It seems relevant to ask what has happened to the Hawke Government's 1983 policy stance that life in this country would be centred around consensus and consultation.
It goes on in its submission:

The Government is playing a strange game. On the one hand it has sent officers of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health scurrying around the country holding rushed, hurried and perfunctory meetings which it terms as `consultations' with an avowed objective of talking with providers, consumers, unions and others with an interest in aged care matters. On the other hand it has introduced yet another Bill (the last was the Nursing Homes and Hostels Legislation Amendment Bill 1987) in what is nothing less than a fait accompli without intending to consult at all at what amounts to some major changes in approach and practice.

In the correspondence the private sector refers to the actions of the Department on 11 November 1987, refers to the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. S303 `Standard for Nursing Home Care', and states that this:

. . . was dropped on an unsuspecting industry, again without consultation, purporting to place into legal terms the so-called Outcomes (Living in a Nursing Home) Manual. But in actual fact it is an awful hotchpotch of an amateurish attempt that runs counter to medical, nursing and legal realities and practices.

This is the opinion of the industry about this Government's implementation of aged care in Australia. We have had damning criticism from all branches of the Voluntary Care Association. We are receiving the same damning criticism of the same type, that is, no consultation, an amateurish implementation and lack of practical knowledge about the implications of what the Government is proposing. The submission by the Australian Nursing Homes Association said, and it is relevant to look at some of these other criticisms:
The Government constantly declines to do so-
referring to consultation-
preferring to suffer the constant mess and aggravations of its blind pursuit of what now is simply change for the sake of change.

The Nursing Homes Association goes on to make a number of specific comments concerning the content of this Bill that we are considering tonight. Basically it is concerned about the discretionary power that appears to be granted to the Minister. It is concerned about the implications for business in giving the discretion to the Minister. It believes that business that is skilled in running a particular type of nursing home, for example, one for geriatric patients, may be directed to conduct a new home as a result of ministerial discretion for, say, disabled persons or some other specific purpose, perhaps an area in which they have no expertise and perhaps inappropriate equipment, and it considers that to be unrealistic. It would be interesting to hear the Minister's comments on the scope of the discretion that this Bill gives him and on the concerns of the industry.
It is concerned about clause 27, that it was supposed simply to clarify ministerial power to review the Secretary's decisions. A key concern that it has is:

. . . the review powers of the Minister would be restricted so as not to allow for consideration of appeals on matters outside the Principles, even though such matters could be the result of human errors. The present law allows for such a review process by the Minister.

In fact there is less capacity under this legislation for the Department or the Minister to react to mistakes and problems as a result of the removal of that particular area of discretion. There is also concern about the Government's commitment to establish a Standards Review Panel. In its submission it says:

There is no real commitment on the Government's part to the establishment of a Standards Review Panel in each State. A pilot scheme was proposed for New South Wales, but is not yet operative. A firm commitment needs to be given for all States . . .

That having been said, it raises a number of other points. It raises the question of what happens in the case of a nursing home dispute in the opinion of the Standards Review Panel. Is there an appropriate appeal mechanism from that particular panel? It questions the Government's intentions in this area. It is again a case of failure to consult, concern within the industry and a degree of insecurity as to what is happening in this industry. We are not talking about only the vast capital investments that it takes to provide aged care in this country. I am sure that all honourable members know that aged care is a rapidly growing problem for our community, a problem which is going to absorb increasing resources in years to come.

As I said in my opening remarks, the Opposition has no real criticism of the Government's direction in this area. Our concern is the concern of the industry-that is, that the policy is being implemented by bureaucrats in Canberra who do not have the capacity or the willingness to consult effectively with the industry and, as a result, there is growing disquiet, growing alarm and growing concern among industry operators, both voluntary and private, and that concern is flowing through to the residents. We are talking about people who have a limited capacity to look after themselves in physical, mental and financial terms, and that concern is spreading through to the community. The damage that has been done to the credibility of the Government's policy in this area by the crisis in Victoria is immense. The possibility of it spreading to other States is real. We must regard the comments of the industry in this area as most important.

The Australian Nursing Homes Association has a number of other criticisms of the provisions of this Bill. It refers to a clause which proposes to introduce a harsh penalty when the Department is approaching the defining of the records required to be maintained. It says that the definition is highly questionable and highly disturbing. It says, again, that the lack of practical knowledge and experience in running a nursing home has already led to extravagant and inappropriate requests being made, to the consternation and frustration of the industry. It refers extensively to the consequences of clause 30. At a later stage in the debate we will make specific comments and move amendments regarding this matter.

Many other individual operators in the industry have raised with me their concerns about specific aspects of this legislation. One large operator, Mr Doug Moran, a private operator, someone who is interested in making a profit on his investments in this area, has written at length about the ministerial review of decisions under section 40ae and the records to be kept for the inspections and questioning of proprietors. As an existing operator in the industry, he has practical experience of the provisions and also the impact of the provisions on operators in the industry. In his letter to me he stated:
Currently section 60b and 61 empower an authorised officer of the Department to demand that-
(1) Proprietors furnish certain records and books;
(2) Proprietors keep records and books in a certain manner;
(3) Additional records and books have to be maintained;
(4) The records are available for inspection at any reasonable time.

That seems to be a reasonable undertaking from anyone who is in receipt of government funds for the conduct of an activity. Mr Moran adds that he understands that the Department has successfully prosecuted some nursing home operators who operate their nursing homes in a fraudulent manner under the existing legislation, with access to the existing records required under the existing legislation. He says:

They consider the amendments to the Act to encompass the questioning of the proprietors and the obtaining of statements is unduly severe, given the success of the current Act. The amendments proposed appear to indicate that the use of Gestapo-type tactics to harass and intimidate proprietors may be applied to extract information.

That is a very significant criticism, in light of the general criticism that has been made by the industry about the lack of consultation and the lack of a genuine practical understanding about the day to day operations of a nursing home. Mr Moran suggests that the Department, in drafting this Bill, has not given due consideration to the rights of a proprietor and in his opinion it could be an example of the denial of natural justice. In his letter he makes reference to the impact of the Government's policy on nursing homes in Victoria. He states:

. . . several nursing homes in Victoria are being administered by an Official Manager owing to the introduction of the nursing homes and hostels review from 1 July 1987. Many other proprietors are experiencing cash flow problems owing to the relatively low amount set for the standard aggregate module (SAM). It is hoped that some information could be obtained as to when the level of SAM may be reviewed.

That particular section of the correspondence is particularly relevant because it has a distinct bearing on why the Opposition is moving an amendment which has been, I believe, circulated in my name. That amendment reads:

``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Hawke Labor Government's autocratic approach to aged care is jeopardising the successful implementation of its policy in Australia, and has seriously threatened stability and future improvements in this most important area, especially-
(a) its refusal to consult on this legislation with voluntary and private sector providers of aged care;
(b) the removal of ministerial discretion in reviewing fees determinations decisions;
(c) the unnecessary, costly and excessive reporting requirements imposed by the Bill;
(d) the duplication of State Government regulations relating to standards; and
(e) the exclusion of private investment from the provision of hostel accommodation''.

As I said in my opening remarks, this is a very important area of policy for any government. It is a very expensive area of policy. It is an area in which all Australians have either a direct or indirect interest, because we will all at one time, hopefully, in our lives contemplate our aged years and how we will provide the sort of security that we all need.

The Government has a fine policy direction. There is a need for more diversity in care; there is a need for a more efficient approach to the provision of that care. But, in the implementation of that policy, it is falling down. That is of genuine concern to me. I note that the Minister is busy reading his notes and that he has a number of advisers in the House at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to understand your amendments; you might explain them to me.

—I hope that they have been listening carefully to my remarks because I have not made them up and I have not sought these remarks from the industry. They have been proffered to us as a result of genuine concern. If it were just one industry sector-for example, the private sector-I would be inclined to say, perhaps, that what it is saying is not entirely balanced. But the remarks have come from both the voluntary sector and the private sector of the industry and from all sections of both sectors of the industry. The comments reinforce each other-that is, that the Department is autocratic, that there has been no consultation and that the legislation has been drafted without a significant practical understanding of its impact.

SPEECH.PARA: We should consider the empirical evidence that we have regarding the state of nursing homes in Victoria. We have correspondence from nursing home operators that draws to our attention the inadequate financial support that has been given and the failure of the Government to follow through some of the proposals that it has indicated to the industry it will be following through. The consultations with the people with expertise are not seen as being reflected in the legislation. Having regard to these matters, the community at large has a reason for justified concern. It is for those reasons that we have proposed a number of amendments.

At a later stage I will explain those amendments in some detail but, having regard to the Minister's comments, let me explain briefly what they are. We are concerned that the Bill prohibits the involvement of private capital in the provision of hostel accommodation. That is of some considerable relevance to the Government, which I believe is particularly concerned about its ability to finance future public sector investments. The high profile issues, of course, are airlines and the Commonwealth Bank. Closer to home, and to the average Australian, are issues such as child care and aged care. In terms of child care, the public sector is up for an immense bill if it is to provide child care on a public sector basis for all Australian children. That, patently, cannot be done. In terms of aged care facilities, a Government that talks about selling Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines surely should welcome capital contributions from the private sector for the provision of aged care.

I would be the first to admit that there is a need to provide adequate regulations to ensure that the involvement of the private sector does not end up being an open-ended commitment to continued funding for ongoing recurrent costs for those particular facilities. That, of course, is another question. It is a question of determining effectively on what basis one will allow private capital investment in this area. We would have more and, perhaps, more diverse hostel accommodation if private capital were allowed to be invested in this area.

We are also proposing a series of amendments which will limit the information and the way in which that information is to be maintained by nursing home proprietors. We accept the arguments of the industry that there are existing requirements for the provision of information. We acknowledge that the Commonwealth has a right to obtain information from nursing home proprietors, be they private or voluntary, on the way they operate their homes, to the extent that either capital or recurrent Commonwealth Government funding is involved. But we do not accept that the Department should go on an information gathering exercise that is not necessary to administer the Federal Government's involvement, and we do not accept a duplication of reporting requirements currently imposed on nursing home operations by State government regulations.

It is also important to recognise that the standards for nursing homes are regulated by State governments. In this debate we must not neglect the involvement of State governments. In debates in this House there is a tendency to ignore the other levels of government, but in regard to nursing homes and aged care provision generally, State governments have a major role in setting standards and monitoring the operations of those facilities. It is a matter that we should keep foremost in mind when considering legislation because the last thing we should be doing is duplicating standards and regulations. Albeit attractive to some bureaucrats to engage in a little bit of empire building by requiring the same information that is provided to State officers, neither the industry nor Australia at large should be required to bear the cost. We should be examining the most effective implementation of an aged care policy which, as I said, will provide effective, compassionate care-and a diversity of care-to meet the needs of the aged. We need to have both nursing home and hostel care and to provide facilities for care in homes. We need to maximise the involvement of the community, both voluntary organisations and private investors. Only through both mechanisms will we have the capacity-and our capacity, no matter how we go about it, will be strained-to provide the necessary facilities for a rapidly aging population.

There has been considerable debate about income security for the aged and the problems that we will face in the coming years as our population grows older and more and more people approach retirement age, but regrettably there has not been the same high public profile for the debate on the provision of aged care. It is a complex area which contains a number of fundamental threshold issues which must be considered. This Bill does not address those issues and I do not propose to canvass them tonight. But it concerns me that the Government up until now, having spent five years in office, does not seem to be effectively addressing the welfare policy issues associated with the provision of aged care. TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the words of wisdom from the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck).
