SPEECH.PARA: By the year 2040 Australia's population's characteristics will be significantly different from what they are today, in 1987. Australia, like the rest of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development nations, is growing older through a combination of lower birth rates and longer life spans. This change will inevitably lead to a reduction in the size of the work force and an increased financial challenge to society to maintain and to improve pensions, health care and welfare services to the aged.

Currently, about 10 per cent of our population is aged 65 and over. By the year 2040 this figure will have at least doubled. The policy decisions to handle this transition have to be put into place now and the amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act and the associated legislation which we are debating tonight are part of that transition. The past few years have seen a deliberate shift in emphasis from institutionalised care provided by nursing homes to the home and community care (HACC) schemes. The shift is based on a number of considerations, two of the most important being that the vast majority of aged persons do not wish, or need, to move into institutional care. Secondly, the quality of care and life provided within the `own home' environment is generally of a higher standard.

This Bill has the principal aim of introducing revised capital funding arrangements for hostels and better management of recurrent funding for new nursing homes. These measures will enhance targeting of funding on a needs basis. Hostel care provides a reasonable medium between the intensive care offered by nursing homes and the often unsuitability of family homes to meet the requirements of old age. In my electorate hostel care, built by capital grants from this Government, is offering an excellent service to many aged people.

There have been problems associated with the move towards greater use of hostel-type accommodation. For instance, the allocation of capital funds has not been directly linked to the capacity of the prospective residents. This has sometimes meant that Commonwealth capital funds went to hostels catering for those not in the greatest need and which have the ability to fund their own care without government recurrent funding. As with all scarce resources, funding for these projects must be targeted to those in need. This amending legislation will aid this in two ways. Firstly, entry contributions paid by residents will be able to be taken into account when determining matching funds for Commonwealth capital grants. This will mean the removal of a burden which now exists on many organisations. Secondly, the Minister will be given power to impose conditions on the capital grant. These conditions will be aimed at ensuring that the disadvantaged do benefit from the grant and the building of more hostel places.

Hence, the Aged or Disabled Persons Homes Act will be amended by the addition of a new division 3 which allows for conditions, such as the class or classes of persons to be accommodated at the hostel, to be placed on capital grant. A similar power is allowed on allocations of recurrent funding. This power is important so that nursing home and hostel care does not become a second rate or cheap option for our nation's aged. Residential care must be accompanied by a well co-ordinated system of medical support and home services, such as maintenance and cleaning. These services are being provided, but in my opinion more must be done if hostels and home care are to remain a real and viable alternative to nursing homes.

I will refer to the situation in my own electorate to illustrate how the system of capital and recurrent funding operates and how it will be improved by the amendments proposed. In Queensland, the allocation of resources is based on a regional system. By this, the State is divided into some 13 regions, each having a community of interest in a wide sense. Much of the electorate of Fisher is contained within the Moreton North region. This region covers the local authority areas of part of Brisbane, Redcliffe, Pine Rivers, Caboolture, Landsborough and Maroochydore. The allocation of resources between regions is decided on the proportion of aged person aged 70-plus within each region. Generally, the ratio used is 100 places for every 1,000 in the target age group. This is divided on the basis of 60 per cent hostel places and 40 per cent nursing home beds. The numbers within the target group are reviewed periodically. Within a region, local authority areas are used as a model for the likely distances it can reasonably be expected that a person should travel to take a nursing home or hostel place.

When an assessment has been made and a need determined within a region, applications are invited by the Department for the offered places. Generally many applications will be received for each offer. At this stage, the new guidelines proposed under the Bill will come into place. In the past, organisations within high need but low socio-economic status areas could be disadvantaged by the factors I have just outlined-that is, first, there being no direct link between capital and recurrent funding; and, secondly, the non-eligibility of resident contributions to determine matching funding. As a result, some areas have become, in relative terms, over-serviced. The new scheme, with appropriate conditions will ensure that this does not happen in the future.

Applications for some 20 nursing home beds and 34 hostel places have recently been sought for the North Moreton region. The areas identified as high need include the Pine Rivers Shire and the Landsborough Shire. There is, however, another area of high need which may not be highly rated due to the overall provision of facilities within the local authority area. This area is Bribie Island within the Caboolture Shire. Bribie Island has traditionally been a retirement area for working class couples. As a result, over 1,000 people fall within the 70-plus age group, yet only 30 nursing home beds are provided as are inadequate numbers of hostel places. Although it is not strictly within the scope of this Bill, I hope there is within the determination process, sufficient flexibility to recognise the special needs of traditional retirement areas so that facilities are provided within the community of greatest need and not discounted due to facilities in other districts, but within the same local authority area. When guidelines are considered for hostel capital grants, I hope that the relationship between nursing homes, or other support facilities, are taken into account. It is essential that, at the end of the day, a community has available a range of care options to suit the entire aged community needs.

One amendment which is most welcome is the changes to the collection of financial data from nursing home proprietors. The changes require a standardised accounting procedure which enables comparison of costs between homes as well as ensuring that recurrent grants are actually expended on the care of the aged residents. Although I do not believe that fraud is a major problem in the nursing home sector, there have been some unfortunate examples of both government funding and resident contributions being lost.

If I may, I will conclude by placing this Bill in some sort of overall perspective. The cost of caring for an aged population is increasing, while the size of the work force will not increase at the same rate. The cost of demographic changes must be shared by the entire community. The aim of any government must be to keep the living standards of the elderly in line with those of the community as a whole. Pensions are being increased over time, both in real and relative terms. The provision of care facilities must also increase to take account of the greying of Australia. The emphasis on home style hostel care as well as family home support agencies is both economically compelling as well as socially required. The system must be needs-based, with those able to provide financially for their old age required to do so. This Bill will help the system become more needs-based as well as more financially responsible. I commend the Bill and it has my support.

I believe that, even though the Secretary must give prior written notice of his requirement, there is no limit on what he can demand, including perhaps private personal health records of staff and former staff, which would undoubtedly represent an intrusion on the privacy of those employed.

I would like to come back briefly to the point about our ending up with nursing homes with a total complement of NH10 patients, because I do believe that that is the thrust of the direction the Minister is following. So nursing homes will have only extensive care patients. I believe it will become incredibly difficult to get appropriate nursing staff to staff those homes. The reality is that even in an ordinary district hospital the work load is spread over totally bedridden patients, ambulatory patients, convalescing patients and patients receiving a variety of procedures which do not require extensive or even intensive nursing care. So we will end up with nursing homes in which everybody is perhaps not bedridden but certainly in need of a great deal of care.

For a couple of reasons I do not think it will be in the interests of those patients to be in that situation. Firstly, the impact on the staff is likely to be very negative and, secondly, nursing homes will find it very difficult to attract the staff that they need. Having been a visitor to many nursing homes around Australia I think that the impact of this legislation on the people who are bed ridden or who are NH10 patients, without the leavening of other patients, without the stimulation, will not be in the best interests of those patients. It will have a very negative influence.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are drawing a long bow now.

—The honourable member says that I am drawing a long bow but he has to realise-I am sure he does as he is a medico; he must realise better than I do-that if every patient in a hospital, be it a nursing home or a district hospital, is bedridden the work load on the nursing staff is extraordinarily high. I have been in nursing homes in the last few days and I have seen the impact of NH5 patients on bedridden patients. The NH5 patients are able to talk to, visit and stimulate bedridden patients. I have no hesitation in saying that I firmly believe that it will be in the best interests of nursing home patients, of elderly Australians, if they can be in a situation which is close to normal. I notice that in some of the material I have reference to this matter is made in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. It is signed by the Minister for Community Services and Health who is at the table. On 10 November 1987 the Gazette states:

SPEECH.PARA: The nursing home will provide accommodation in which the design, furnishings and practices are as homelike as possible-
and who can argue with that-
and in which residents follow a routine similar to that of the general community.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to consider for one moment the statement that `the residents follow a routine similar to that of the general community'. The general community is not bedridden. The general community is not composed 100 per cent of NH10 patients. The general community is composed of a broad spectrum of people. I again submit that the welfare of the NH10 patients is going to be better served where there is that evening of people.

Clause 27 of the Bill appears to be helpful to proprietors where the Secretary has imposed conditions on a nursing home which is the subject of review and where the proprietor opposes those changes; having made applications is opposed to the Department's decision; or has his application refused. In passing I say that clause 28 is a very sensible clause in that it gives time to proprietors to adapt before the establishment of the Standard Review Panel in each State.

Clauses 29 and 30 cause considerable concern because they are particularly wide in their application and, in effect, give what some people have referred to as police state powers to departmental officers. Whilst the requirement to keep all relevant records at the nursing home or at some other agreed location is not unreasonable, the extent of documentation to be kept is not made clear and this at least should be clarified. Powers to visit a nursing home at any time, question any person under threat of six months in gaol, a fine of $1,000 or both, are very intimidating particularly as the person may not have been an employee of the nursing home at any time. It is that broad. Further, the rejection of the notion that a person should not be expected to incriminate himself is also very disturbing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is as bad as the ID card.

—It is certainly as bad as the ID card. Naturally, it would be preferred if the Bill provided an intermediate step of directing the Department to send to the proprietor a list of questions for answer, supported by appropriate documentation. And only if those answers were incomprehensible, inappropriate or incomplete should the Department then have power to seek a court order enabling it to make use of the powers sought in this proposed legislation. I sug- gest that the powers in this legislation are un-Australian and certainly contrary to the spirit of fairness that we as Australians believe should prevail. In speaking about the question of records to be kept, inspections and the questioning of proprietors and their staff, currently section 60b and 61 of the principal Act, empower an authorised officer of the Department to demand that, first, proprietors furnish certain records and books; second, that proprietors keep records and books in a certain manner; third, that additional records and books be maintained; and fourth, that records be available for inspection at any reasonable time.

SPEECH.PARA: Those powers are there already. I believe that the Department has already successfully prosecuted some nursing home proprietors who deserve prosecution. Therefore, I believe that the present Act is successful in that area and that there is no need to amend it, to introduce these incredibly draconian requirements. The rights of a proprietor as a normal person do not appear to have been considered. Certainly, this would appear to be a prime example of the denial of natural justice. It is appropriate to refer to proposed new section 61d because it empowers an authorised officer to enter premises with the consent of the occupier, to apply to a justice of the peace for a warrant authorising entry to premises, to apply to a justice of the peace for a warrant authorising entry to premises with such assistance and force as is necessary, to search the premises, and to inspect and make copies of documents and records that are on the premises.

I return to the possibility of applying to a justice of the peace for a warrant authorising entry to premises with such assistance and force as are necessary. This is Australia. We are talking about nursing homes in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, and mine. In what conceivable circumstances can you imagine any nursing in your electorate, or mine, being in a situation where force had to be used to gain entry to look at documents? The whole thing is absolutely crazy.

I return to the changes introduced under the home and community care (HACC) scheme and what is popularly known in the industry as the red book. In many instances the whole principle of the red book has been resisted by people within the industry-not by all, but certainly by some. What can be said quite clearly is that the problems of the aged care system which have arisen since the present Government came to power have been blowing up and will continue to blow up. In terms of the red book, the proprietors of private nursing homes, particularly those who have provided all of the funding without 1c of Commonwealth capital funding, object to the assessment teams deciding who will occupy beds. In some of the establishments in my electorate there is not only a nursing home but also a hostel and self-care unit. The people who go into these self-care units have provided the money for them. The people who built the whole establishment have provided the capital funding on the basis that they can have the use of one of those beds when required. I think it is fair and reasonable that they should be able to object to assessment teams deciding who will occupy those beds.

They are also concerned that assessment teams will regularly reassess patients and attempt to discharge them from homes. We in this place all know that that is one of the possibilities. We all know that the assessment teams are going in with the belief that people will be getting better in health and in their situations and they should be discharged from the nursing home. But to where? In so many cases the people in nursing homes have sold their homes; they have nowhere to go. In many cases their families are not close by. They are alone and their home is the nursing home. No matter whether they go from being NH10 patients to NH5 patients, there is no justice in saying to elderly Australian men or women in their eighties or nineties, `Get out of this nursing home. You are a bit better. Go and find somewhere else to live'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very debilitating.

—Indeed, and this is the reality. The assessment teams are working on the premises put forward in the red book. Again, the assessment teams will decide the quality of the bed to be occupied, whether it is to be a one-bedroom, two- or four-bed multiple ward. This is irrespective of whether the patients are able and willing to pay a greater fee for better care. Why, if Australian citizens have the financial resources to pay for a better standard of care, should they not be allowed to pay for it? After all, what sort of society are we? I know that those on the Government benches are determined to bring everybody down to the same level. We can see this by what the Government is saying about its wealth inquiry. I would rather have an inquiry about poverty. I am concerned about poverty; I am not concerned about wealth. The more wealth there is, the more wealthy Australians there are, the better, as far as I am concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: It is just not possible to run a quality nursing home by charging all patients a standard fee of 87.5 per cent of the pension. I am talking about nursing homes where the capital funding has been provided by private people, and the capital funding has provided superior, first rate accommodation. I am not suggesting that the majority of nursing homes do not provide good accommodation. I am talking about the possibility-I have seen accommodation which is far superior-of people who have the funds being allowed to create and live in the environment which they are used to. Quite apart from the point I made about people being thrown out by assessment teams, with nowhere to go, if people have been used to a certain standard of living all their lives, if they have the resources to continue to live like that, why should they be forbidden to do it?

I would like to come back to the point that it is not possible to have nursing homes only for NH10 or bed-ridden patients. I know that this is what the Minister proposes, but I say to him and to the people of Australia that I believe this is totally wrong. It will not work at all. The thought of NH5 or walking patients being put into hostels at a lower fee also will not work, because the proprietors could not care for such patients at a lower hostel fee. The instruction that proprietors must accept 20 per cent of ethnic, Aboriginal or retarded patients straight out of Gladesville, Rozelle or Morisett is one which concerns me greatly. I think this needs to be looked at again.

The basic principle enunciated since the Minister has had control of this, that no more nursing home beds will be provided, is very wrong indeed. Such is the demand for nursing home care in Australia that every bed we have now is occupied, but strangely enough, this Labor Government has the idea that a proportion will be available as respite beds. What we need is not fewer nursing home beds, but more. This is the reality. And we certainly need respite beds, which are not available. As we all know, all of those beds are occupied right now.

I repeat that I believe it is an excellent idea that elderly Australians should be encouraged to live in their own home environment for as long as possible. But they have to have the infrastructure support to enable them to do so, and that just does not exist-it is not there. We hear, not daily but frequently, about Meals on Wheels having to be reduced. This is symptomatic of the whole situation. What we need in this country is a continuation of the dual system of care. We need the opportunity for free enterprise nursing homes to carry on providing the care that they are providing so well already. We do not need a system that brings everybody down to the same level. What we need is a system of care for elderly Australians, where everybody gets the care that they can afford, but certainly a base minimum, which is that provided under the system. I do not think that those Australians who have the opportunity of doing something better should be knocked and treated as tall poppies, no matters what their ages. I think this is the basic difference in philosophy. We need to give everyone in Australia a fair go.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who unfortunately arrived late for the debate-I do not think that is a reflection of his concern for the aged in our community-entreated that we take an apolitical stance in this debate. Considering the contributions of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), I would say that unfortunately his colleagues do not endorse that view. The honourable member for Cowper expressed the view that we should provide for our old people a situation which is as close to normal as possible, and surely that is an endorsement of the trust of the policy of this Government. We are trying, wherever possible, to encourage aged people to remain at home and to have assistance at home. Alternatively, we have a hostel and nursing home system which we believe provides for the very special circumstances of those who are unable to stay at home. The honourable member expressed the concern that the wealthy aged should be provided with special facilities in nursing homes so that they can have a higher standard of care than others. Unfortunately, for the vast majority of old people in my electorate that is not the issue at all. If they had the means, as he suggests, to be able to be provided with a special kind of care, perhaps they would stay at home and employ a nursing sister or some sort of assistant to help look after them. But for the vast majority of the older people in my electorate the problem is finding a nursing home or hostel bed. They are quite happy with the standards that the Government believes are appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Richmond agreed with the direction that this Government has taken. He believed that there needs to be a diversity, a mix between institutional care in nursing homes and hostels and our home and community care program, which increasingly is providing assistance for people at home. He believed that there needs to be more efficiency and accountability in the provision of residential care for aged people. Whilst I understand the resistance to change by members of the Opposition, I believe it is necessary for us to get the facts right when we talk about providing for aged people and the record of this Government. If we look at the two issues which are perhaps of most concern to aged people, health and financial support, in both of those areas, I think it is clear to the aged in our community that this Government has provided very substantial assistance. It has provided in Medicare and in its health scheme a very reliable and constant form of health cover. Old people know, as all of the community knows, that it is there and that it will provide for them if they need it. It is in contradistinction to the recent plan announced on 5 November by the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The headline in the Australian of that day said: `Elderly would pay higher premiums in Tuckey health plan'. Indeed, great consternation was caused by that announcement. Soon after, having been dressed down by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Tuckey health plan was shelved and has not been seen since.

If we look at the Government's record on pensions we find that since 1983 the amount of the pension has increased to just on 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, as the Government said it would. Indeed, since 1983 there has been an increase in the pension in real terms of 8.3 per cent. Clearly, in its provision of assistance in the areas of health and financial support for the aged, this Government has met its commitments. But what are the objections of the Opposition to this issue?

To seek to offer further comment in a position where only the honourable member could hear it, was, I think, a reflection upon the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I must say that I am not at all concerned about the interjections of the honourable member opposite. It has been said in this debate by our opponents that we should not make a political issue of the aged debate. I say to you that if the Government wished to make it a political issue, I am sure that our stance on the assets test would not have been the one that we took, which, at the time, was economically rational and sensible for long term planning, when one thinks about the funding of aged care in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It was suggested, of course, by members of the Opposition that private investment in the area of hostels, as it relates to the provisions of this Bill, should be allowed. Of course, the Government's review into nursing homes believed that this may not be the most acceptable way of going about things. Certainly, there was consultation with voluntary and religious groups. It was their view that they would like to be able to provide assistance in this area. Indeed, one opens a can of worms when one talks about all of the boarding houses which presently exist throughout our community and the likelihood of having to decide, within the guidelines of hosteliers, whether they were appropriate sources to provide hostel care. Of course, there has been extensive consultation, but eventually governments have to make decisions. They make decisions which they believe are balanced; they balance the compassion that is necessary when caring for old people with that of the economic rationale which is most important in this area. It is also important that those public funds which are spent in this area be accountable. Of course, it is most important that any money which is spent, which the Government allocates for providing aged care, be spent correctly.

During the weekend I had the opportunity to read a report which arrived on my desk on Friday, entitled Australia's population trends and prospects 1987. It was produced by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. It makes very sobering reading for those of us who are looking at the issue of providing assistance for aged care. The report states, in effect, that undoubtedly one of the most important demographic issues to face the world is the rapid growth in the number of elderly. Whereas in 1985 only 5.9 per cent of the world's population was aged 65 years and over, by 2025 nearly 10 per cent of the population will be aged over 65.

Of course, in Australia the figures are much greater. Those figures have been accelerating for most of the twentieth century. In Australia the level is now 10.5 per cent, and if we look 40 years hence to the year 2025, 17.6 per cent of Australia's population will be aged over 65. What is perhaps more significant than the number of people over 65 is the number over 75. Indeed, over the next 40 years that number will more than triple. It is salutary to look at the figures, which suggest that 40 years hence nearly two million Australians will be over 75 years of age.

Clearly, it is important for us to understand from this report that the per capita cost to the public of funding the elderly is three times the cost of funding young dependent people. It is important for us to understand that as our population grows older, there will be more and more old people who are dependent on fewer and fewer wage and salary earners. While there will be fewer taxpayers, more old people will be receiving pensions and benefits and will be in need of care in their final years. In those circumstances, the Government needs a long term plan, a long term strategy. It needs to streamline its assistance and the sort of programs that it develops. It needs to be accountable to the public for the money that it allocates in that way.

This Bill is part of a staged program of reform of residential care services for aged people. It was commenced in the 1986-87 Budget and followed a review of nursing homes and hostels which was brought down by the Government in April 1986. The first two stages of the program were outlined by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in his second reading speech. They concerned the establishment of new needs based planning arrangements, the development of co-ordinated assessment services for the elderly, the expansion of hostel and home and community care services, the development of a special services program, the phasing in of new recurrent funding arrangements for non-government nursing homes from 1 July 1987, and the introduction of quality of care standards for nursing homes.

This legislation represents the third stage of that program. It introduces new variable funding arrangements for hostels. It will improve the provision for the disadvantaged to gain access to hostel accommodation. Within the arrangements special consideration is given to the number of disadvantaged people who will have access to and be resident of a particular hostel. It also provides encouragement for eligible groups who are involved in the provision of hostels to use their own funds and to use the entry contributions of residents for the provision of hostel care. Indeed, it will ensure that appropriate links are made between the capital and recurrent funding that the Government provides for hostels.

Although many members of the Opposition dwelt on nursing home care in their contributions tonight, the Bill provides for accountability. Standardised accounting procedures, as the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) said in his very thoughtful contribution, are important. It is necessary and perfectly reasonable that in providing for nursing home administration, there should be a standardised accounting system that appropriately provides for government to review the expenditure in nursing homes.

Finally, this omnibus legislation gives effect to our commitment to transfer, by 1993, nursing education out of hostels and into the tertiary sector. Since the report of the Sax Committee there has been a great deal of talk about this move. When we came to government I, and many other members of the Government, received a great deal of lobbying from members of the nursing sectors because of their belief that it was necessary for us to make this move. Indeed, the Government has given effect to it and this legislation provides the wherewithal to continue that move into 1993.

It is important for the Opposition to learn, as we have, that the public purse is not endless. The honourable member for Cowper hopes that we will provide more and more nursing home beds. We need to provide more nursing home beds in total terms, but in real terms, as a percentage of our population, it is necessary for us to allocate resources more efficiently. This Government knows that it has to plan for the long term and it has moved in this legislation and in other legislation to put in place a long term plan for residential care for aged people.

The direction of the Government is endorsed by me and, while members of the Opposition may snipe at the details, it provides for efficient use of resources, allows for hostel quotas to be met and opens up new avenues for eligible organisations. It tightens up the accountability for nursing homes and it gives effect to our commitment to transfer nursing education to the tertiary sector. It has my wholehearted support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order having been restored, I shall address briefly the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill, in view of the fast eroding time available to me. Honourable members may recall that earlier in the day I had the opportunity in a different context to express some philosophical views as to what we should do about the state of our nation and, by extension, the health and welfare facilities that are available to our citizens, on the premise that they may need them in the circumstances I described. Those circumstances may be regarded as paradise desired, in the full knowledge that should we stumble upon paradise it would probably take us no more than 24 hours to ruin the place. However, that is an aside. Notwithstanding my earlier remarks, the essential consideration is that I wish this evening briefly to address this Bill in terms of the world in which we live rather than that which we might desire.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two particular matters that I wish to address. The first is the broadly accepted and thoroughly defensible proposition that nursing homes should be precisely that-for persons who require nursing. That is not to be confused with the accommodation which is necessary for aging people but which falls short of nursing care. Nursing homes are synonymous with nursing care-not care by those with lesser qualifications who may well attend to the requirements of people, say, in hostels, but not to be confused with nursing care appropriate to nursing home accommodation as at presently contemplated.

It stands to reason by that very measure that if nursing homes are to be reserved for those in need of nursing care, there must be an additional cost to the nursing home management to provide that extra care and attention. It takes little imagination to realise that the difference between ordinary care as we presently understand it and extra care for exclusively nursing home patients must be significant. It is important that in addressing this matter the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) should ensure that the purpose of the project is not defeated as a consequence of nursing homes lacking the financial ability to achieve the objective.

The other aspect which interests me greatly is respite care. Reference to respite care has been made during a rather broad canvassing of this Bill this evening. I put the additional point that, although we all recognise the advantages of respite care, at present we seem to be locked into a situation that this provision must be ancillary to already existing establishments or those proposed within the conventional nursing home environment. There are people in the community who would be of a mind on a non-profit basis to provide exclusive independent, free-standing respite care facilities. It is most important that any community should have adequate recourse to such facilities. It must be recognised that the Government, in its wisdom, has brought out a policy which has laid considerable emphasis on retaining aged people within their own homes in their own domestic environment for as long as possible. I believe that there is a great deal to commend that.

The corollary of that laudable policy is that those who are required to oversee, supervise and attend such people in their own homes fall victim to an increasingly demanding human situation, to the extent that they themselves in turn could suffer a setback because of their enslavement-and I use the word with proper connotations-to the needs of the people whom we now seek to keep in their homes. The value of having respite centres where those people may be relieved for a week, two weeks, a month or whatever it may be would prove to be invaluable and would support rather than undermine the Government's policy of keeping people in their homes. I have not been able to satisfy myself thus far that there is an immediate sensitivity by the Government to that requirement. I doubt whether the Government has thoroughly identified it. In a nebulous way the Government appreciates the value of respite care, but at present it is locked into a more conventional mode as distinct from a proposition for independent, self-contained respite centres to give full care to people we seek to keep in their homes for a period that would depend on the demand and the number of units available for respite care. I see no discord emanating from that proposal. It seems eminently logical and totally consistent with what the Government appears to be doing.

Thus far those who have had an ambition to establish such facilities have found themselves in the invidious position of not being accommodated by any Government legislative program. I am sure that the Minister, in addressing that need more assiduously than has been done thus far, will recognise that there is advantage not only in terms of the community but also of properly putting into place and maintaining the policy of retaining people in their own homes. It is a corollary of the policy to maintain aged citizens in their own homes.

I prefaced my remarks with the observation that I was mindful of the fact that time is fast eroding and that other legislation is still to come before the House. I would only recapitulate, if I went further on matters which have been adequately advanced this evening by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and other members on both sides of the House. On those two points I seek assurance from the Government that if it is not in a position of being able immediately to accommodate those matters, they are very much in the Government's thoughts.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for participating in the debate on the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. In response to the novel proposal by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) as to respite care, which he had the courtesy to mention to me earlier, I make the point that the Government is addressing such proposals. The Government has had discussions with the communities involved and will be looking at the matter, along with a range of options for the further development of respite care.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has moved an amendment, which is the best way of structuring my reply to the comments which have been made in this debate. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) devoted much of his time to talking about a lack of consultation and quoting from various epistles and letters, some of which I have seen and some which I have not seen. The ones I have examined touch on marginal and peripheral areas in this Bill, and indeed many of the comments do not relate to this Bill at all. I do not believe that those organisations are doing themselves much credit by commenting on the Bill in this way. The important thing for those organisations, and indeed the Opposition, to recognise is that the central part of this Bill is the proposal for variable funding for hostel provision. This legislation enables government to provide that variable funding. The actual substance of that variable funding would depend on later Acts which are open to disallowance by both this and the other House. I think it is important to realise that the central thrust of this Bill is to enable governments to develop a policy of variable funding for hostels, the substantive details of which will be open to debate and disallowance in both Houses.

The very thrust of this Bill has been widely discussed by the industry. In fact, we sent the report on variable funding to the industry and it has been widely circulated. The principles of variable funding have been widely discussed and accepted. There still remain some issues about the exact nature and amount of that variable funding but those will come forward in later proposals which, as I said, will be subject to disallowance in either House. It seems to me that much of the criticism, which was the essence-as usual, I suppose-of the speech of the honourable member for Richmond, was really rather peripheral and marginal and, on the while, it did not do those organisations very much credit.

The second point, which I find most extraordinary coming from the honourable member for Richmond, is that he is worried about the removal of some of my ministerial discretion. I think it is the first time that the Opposition has told me, as a Minister, that I should have more ministerial discretion. The reason why this ministerial discretion is being removed is that we want to ensure, under the new nursing home proposals, that effectively there is one law for everybody. We want to make it quite clear that individuals will not be able to approach Ministers in the hope that by threat, coercion or special pleading they will be able to get around those basic nursing home principles. It is also designed to ensure that Ministers will not be able to pork barrel in these matters because the principles will bind Ministers as much as they will bind all other members of the community. It will also prevent an unscrupulous Minister-certainly not a Labor Minister-in the future from scapegoating a particular individual or organisation by getting around the principles. In relation to the one specific issue that the honourable member for Richmond raised-that is, the computational mistake-the principles will ensure that that error be corrected as the Minister is bound by those principles.

We then find that the Opposition is somewhat unhappy about the so-called `unnecessary, costly and excessive reporting requirements' imposed by the Bill. One of the problems I have constantly with this Opposition is that while no other Opposition has endeavoured to make more political capital of the way taxpayers' money is being spent, at the same time it attacks every specific measure taken by this Government to ensure those moneys are properly spent and properly accountable, as in this Bill. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) made the very good point-I agree with him entirely-that the money spent by government, $1.15 billion a year on nursing home benefits, is not government money; it is taxpayers' money. As a government, we have to ensure that that $1.15 billion on those benefits is properly paid. That is not an unreasonable requirement. Most of the reports that have come to government-many of the parliamentary reports, often produced by bipartisan committees-have stressed the need for more effective accountability and reporting requirements. One of the specific issues addressed here is something of which I am sure the honourable member for Richmond is aware-that is, that amongst a few of the nursing home proprietors there are efforts to keep records off premises so it makes it more difficult for government to access those records which is necessary if the right and proper amount of money is to be spent. We believe that the specific actions taken in this Bill are necessary in light of our experience to ensure that we, as a government, are properly accountable to the Australian taxpayers for the $1.15 billion of their money spent in the provision of nursing home benefits.

I am surprised that the Opposition should attack the quality of care arrangements on the grounds that they somehow duplicate the work done by the States. Again, most of the various reports that governments have received on nursing home matters in recent years have stressed the need for the Commonwealth, as the chief source of recurrent funding for nursing homes, to have a task of ensuring that that money is spent to produce quality outcomes for old people. Indeed, the report Private Nursing Homes in Australia from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes made this recommendation:

. . . the Commonwealth fund pilot studies to examine quality indicators with a view to introducing these indicators in the assessment of quality of patient care and to provide a basis for thorough nursing home inspections.

That recommendation, which came not just from the Labor Party members of the Committee, but from all members of the Committee, was that we should go ahead to develop outcome quality standards that could be the basis of effective inspection. Again, rather than duplicating the efforts of the States, these proposals have been brought about in co-operation with the States, with which we have worked in drawing up the standards, as well as with the industry itself. I am glad to say that most of the State Ministers have formally endorsed the outcome standards. They do not see them as duplicating their tasks. They see this as a co-operative relationship, particularly with the Commonwealth having this major financial involvement, and they are willing to co-operate to endorse the outcome standards.

Perhaps the most inappropriate of all the statements by the honourable member for Richmond was that the standards were dropped on the unsuspecting industry. There has been an extraordinary process of consultation with industry in developing the standards. The first draft of these standards was circulated in late 1985. I think the industry would, or should, agree that they were largely drafted by the industry in partnership with professionals and consumers. In relation to the standard review panels, the honourable member for Richmond said-either himself or perhaps in this case he was quoting somebody else-that we had an inadequate government commitment. If he reads the Bill he will see that clause 28 makes it perfectly clear that the section 45 sanctions will not apply in any State until a standard review panel is established in that State. The Bill makes clear the Government's commitment that the sanctions attached to these standards will not apply until there is a standard review panel established in that State. Of course, the Government is moving as quickly as possible in co-operation with the industry to establish such standard review panels.

The other issue raised by the Opposition is in relation to private profit investment in the provision of hostel accommodation. It has been the long-standing policy of all governments in this country-the Whitlam Government, the Fraser Government and now the Hawke Government-that private investment has been excluded from hostel accommodation. We intend to continue that long-standing policy which, as I say, has been supported by governments of all political complexions. We are committed to and have announced a substantial expansion in the hostel area. Under this Government's program over 10,000 hostel places will be provided in the next three years, so that with this program and the way in which it is funded, there is a very significant contribution to the expansion of the hostel sector. For those reasons I ask the House to reject the amendment moved by the Opposition.

—As a member of the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency our signing and ratification of the agreement reflects our support for the South Pacific region. It demonstrates Australia's commitment to the development of our strategic, political, economic and social objectives as well as the independence and stability of the region.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said previously, the Treaty is consistent with the principles enunciated in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. Australia has long been a major contributor of funds to the South Pacific fisheries program. Historically, Australia contributes 30 per cent of the budget of the South Pacific Forum Fisheries Agency, which was the co-ordinator of the negotiations and which administers the Treaty. Traditionally, Australia makes a significant contribution through the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau for regional fisheries projects. Australia has financed and sent delegations to every round of negotiations held over the Treaty.

The Treaty was signed by Australia on 2 April this year and was ratified in Port Moresby on 18 May. The amendment to the principal Act, the Fisheries Act 1952, will provide the means by which we can implement the Treaty arrangements. The Treaty will authorise United States tuna purse seine fishing vessels to fish in the licensing area which includes part of the Australian fishing zone around the Coral Sea islands territory. The United States Government is required under the Treaty to enforce the requirements of the Treaty, including preventing unlicensed fishing and by ensuring Treaty licence conditions are complied with. This does not diminish the right of each Pacific island party to enforce the Treaty requirements in its own zone. The Treaty also provides for broader co-operation between the United States and other parties to the Treaty through the United States providing technical and economic support to assist the parties to the Treaty to maximise benefits from their fish resources, including provison of facilities, services and employment opportunities.

This is the first multilateral fisheries access treaty with which Australia has been involved. This Treaty will bring more than $60m to the Pacific nations involved over the next five years. As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) pointed out, Australia's share of that is expected to be about $150,000 per annum. Under this Treaty the United States is being allowed access to a very small area of the Australian fishing zone in the north-eastern Coral Sea which is currently not being exploited by the Australian fishing industry.

One of the major benefits of the Treaty will be access to an assessment of the tuna stocks in the area which will allow Australian operators to assess the commercial viability of the resource. The impact on the area will be only minimal as it is expected that there will be only four to five boats in the zone and that they will not be there are the same time. The Treaty provides for Australia to have observers when they come into the Australian fishing zone. This is particularly relevant in regard to monitoring the dolphins that may unfortunately from time to time be casualties in this operation. Australia has made it quite clear to the United States that the dolphin population in the area will be the subject of stringent monitoring.

While talking of environmental considerations, I am informed that purse seining, the method of fishing to be used by the Americans, is effective on surface schooling fish, or pelagics as they are known, whilst not damaging the deeper swimming varieties. Australia has a great commitment to the work in a number of international fishing organisations that monitor environmental as well as economic aspects of fisheries.

The context that this amendment occurs in is a significant one considering the dispute that the Government of the Solomon Islands has had with United States tuna fishermen over previous years. A treaty such as this rationalises the relationship between countries such as the Solomon Islands and Australia and the United States because it protects the host country and enables it to enter into fair and equitable arrangements with those who seek to exploit its resources. While article 3 of the Treaty permits United States vessels to have access to the licensing area, it requires operators to comply with the relevant national laws.
I conclude by outlining some of the other major features of this Treaty. Article 4 provides:
. . . US Government to take the necessary steps to ensure:
(i) its nationals comply with the Treaty
(ii) all required assistance is given to SP states in the investigation of a breach of the Treaty by a US vessel,
(iii) US vessels licensed pursuant to the Treaty are insured against all risks and liabilities,
(iv) any claim against a US vessel is promptly settled,
(v) service of legal process by or on behalf of an SP State is duly effected,
(vi) any judgment against a US vessel is duly satisfied,
(vii) US vessel leaves the Treaty Area if there was reasonable cause to believe the vessel had been fishing in contravention of the Treaty, except to submit to the jurisdiction of the SP state;
Article 4 of the Treaty continues:

US Government is required to penalise its nationals at such a level as provided for like violations by US law relating to contraventions of the Treaty where the US vessel has not submitted to SP state jurisdiction;

It is my view that these amendments and this Treaty will do a great deal to placate the nation states in the South Pacific against the intrusion in their sovereign waters by the United States tuna fishing fleet, and I believe the Bill is a very positive step and should be supported by the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to some of the remarks made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). I was rather surprised when he started by saying what a positive policy this present Government has towards the Pacific islands. I think one of the great concerns of many people in Australia is the complacency with which this Government has sat back and watched the Soviet Union moving into the Pacific area, moving into what we should have seen as a strategic zone for our own future security. The Government has appeared virtually to condone what has been going on and to ignore the long term effects that this will have on our security.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the honourable member for the Northern Territory, in his concluding remarks, went to great pains to point out the fact that the United States of America should play the game, and I support him on that. But he very neatly ignored the fact that the Soviet Union has been moving in and quietly, or not so quietly, trying to take over some of these fishing areas in the South Pacific. This should be of great concern to all members of this chamber, because the long term effects on our future security could indeed be serious if we do not take this matter a little bit more seriously than the present Government appears to be.

As has been pointed out by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), the Fisheries Amendment Bill amends the Fisheries Act 1952. It satisfies the Treaty, which was brought into place by certain Pacific island states and the Government of the United States of America and which was signed by Australia on 2 April of this year. It will come into force when at least 10 eligible Pacific island states, which, it has been pointed out, must include Papua New Guinea, Kirabiti and the Federated States of Micronesia, have ratified it.

As has also been pointed out, Australia stands to gain revenue of $150,000 up front. If, say, 5 per cent of the fish caught by boats of the United States is caught in Australian waters we would probably end up with a total of about $700,000. This is ongoing, and the United States has agreed to pay all up about $US60m over the next five years. The Treaty will be up for renegotiation after that time. Obviously all honourable members would welcome this move by the United States Government. It is certainly not before time, and it will do much to help some of these Pacific island states which have had to sit by and watch, without any compensation, United States fishermen taking the fish from their waters.

As has also been pointed out, in Australia's case, all the money that is received from the United States, through this Treaty, will be paid into Consolidated Revenue, and part of that will go towards paying for the additional surveillance of that area. It was also pointed out by the honourable member for the Northern Territory that the area covered is only a small part of our extended fishing zone, and it can be seen from page 11 of the explanatory memorandum that it is a section of the north-eastern side of Australia.

The point that really concerns me about this legislation and the time that it has taken is the effect this has had on some of our near neighbours in the Pacific zone and the way they have chosen, or perhaps felt it necessary, to begin to look at the Soviet Union for ways and means of bolstering their income and, of course, in return giving the Soviet Union the chance to get a foothold in the South Pacific, which of course is very much of concern to all Australians and to our future security. Back in July 1985 the Government of Kiribati was saying that it would press ahead with a proposed Soviet tuna fisheries deal, in defiance of mounting opposition from home and other Pacific countries. Neighbouring Tuvalu was also studying a Soviet offer and, according to an article in the Age of July 1985, it was `likely to go ahead'. A little later, on 27 August 1986, the Soviet Union actually signed a $US1.7m agreement. The Canberra Times reported that the Government of Kiribati had signed an agreement:
. . . a year ago to allow Soviet tuna boats to fish within Kiribati's 320 km economic zone, and similar negotiations are under way now with Vanuatu.

It is understood that in August 1986 the Soviet Union also made overtures to Western Samoa and Fiji. It is of great concern when we see the complacency of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) about the intrusion of the Soviets into this area, particularly with the developments in Fiji, because it is quite clear that the Soviets are keen to get a greater foothold in this area and would use it very much as a means of bringing in further strategic defence capabilities in the long run, which no doubt would threaten Australia's security. More recently, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 February 1987, we find-this is even closer to home-the following:
Papua New Guinea's Cabinet agreed on Wednesday that it would consider a fishing deal with Moscow . . .

The warnings are there. They have been there for some time, and the Government appears to be totally complacent about it all. At the end of January this year an article in the Sydney Morning Herald stated:
Vanuatu and the Soviet Union yesterday signed their long-awaited tuna fishing agreement, which is expected to earn the Vanuatu Government US$1.5m in annual royalties.
We then contrast that with the attitude of the present Government. An article on the front page of the Australian of 5 March 1987 reads:
The Australian Government has reversed a 1983 decision and agreed to allow the Soviet Union to conduct a scientific survey of fisheries resources in Australian waters.
The article states that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade made this extraordinary statement that the meeting:
. . . with the Soviet Foreign Minister Mr . . . Shevardnadze, that despite assurances from the Soviet official, he-
that is, Mr Hayden-
remained concerned about Soviet intentions in the South Pacific.
The article went on:
The new agreement also follows closely on Australia's criticism of South Pacific nations for negotiating fishery agreements with the Soviet Union.
Mr Hayden has said in the past, however, it was the inability of those small nations to monitor adequately Soviet activities that concerned him.

What utter humbug. Here he is quite happily saying, `We are going to do a deal'. He has virtually ignored the fact that several of the South Pacific countries have been negotiating agreements, and yet he is apparently prepared to sign a deal for Australia. I think the overall attitude of this Government, over this whole fishing matter, is and should be of great concern to all Australians. On the one hand, we are quite rightly signing a treaty with the United States, but, on the other hand, we seem to be quite complacent about the fact that the Soviet Union is moving in to begin a fishing operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you know that the Soviets are already in Fiji?
—Order! If the honourable member for Hotham believes he is speaking in the adjournment debate, I must remind him that we have not got that far yet.

—As I said, the whole attitude of this Government seems to be a load of humbug. I think, as all honourable members would know, the tactics of the Soviet Union are quite simple in these things. It gains fishing access, then, of course, it needs a base for those fishing boats in case they break down, or for other reasons, whatever they may be. Once it has that base, it needs an airstrip. What does it have then? It has the makings of a military installation that can be set up in a very short time to become a means for offensive as well as defensive measures. It is very interesting to note that the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) signed a letter dated 1986 to the USSR Registrar of Shipping. In part, the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would also draw your attention to the Government's recent decision, subject to certain conditions being met by the USSR, to approve a joint Australia-USSR fisheries research project in the waters adjacent to Heard and Macdonald Islands. The project will involve a Soviet vessel and crew and two Australian scientists and will be the first time that Australia and the USSR have co-operated in the fisheries area.

It is very significant, and even more so when one notes that it was not until March 1987 that what the Government had agreed to some considerable time prior to that date actually became public knowledge. We have a government which almost appears to want to play off both sides at once, which is quite happy to do deals with the Russians on this matter and, equally, is quite complacent when it sees the Russians moving into the South Pacific areas for reasons which are highly questionable and which could in the long term threaten the security of this nation. I think that the complacency of this Government is of great concern, certainly to all members on this side of the House.

I hope that the Government, now that the Treaty has been signed, will take a slightly stronger stand in making sure that the security and future of this country are maintained. As we all know, we still have the semblance of an ANZUS Treaty. That Treaty shows very clearly that our defence is intermingled with that of the United States. We ignore that at our own peril. The Fisheries Amendment Bill has the support of the Opposition, but it does raise some wider issues. I have canvassed those issues because I think they are very important, not only for fishing areas in north-eastern Australia, but also for our whole defence strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time, it was noted that the main concern of Vanuatu, the Solomons and different islands that we had the pleasure of visiting was the fishing rights of their areas and the transgressing generally of United States ships, including mother ships. The fact remains that it was necessary to come to some arrangements between the countries concerned, and this has been done. TALK.START.PARA: —Since I took the opportunity in the grievance debate of 29 October to deal with the fate of the bowls program Jack High, I have been delighted at the number of honourable members who have spoken to me on that matter. They have expressed their concern and outlined the approaches they were making to the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) to have the program restored.
—That is the biggest complaint against the ABC in my electorate at the moment.

—I am gratified to hear that from the Deputy Leader of the National Party. Since I raised the matter I have not heard from the Chairman of the ABC. I do not suppose I should be surprised; I do not expect always to hear from people associated with matters I raise in this House. However, before I spoke in that debate I raised this matter with Mr Jackson, a man responsible for the ABC's corporate image. I let him know that I would be pressing this matter in the Parliament on every available opportunity, unless the ABC saw fit to give some reasonable explanation about its conduct in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to suspend the program Jack High was justified on the basis of budgetary restraint. When I spoke on the matter on 29 October I went through its history. I drew attention to the circumstances in which the ABC had led a number of people to the view that this program would be continued, and to announcements made in South Australia about plans to present Jack High during the bicentennial year. On that occasion I also spoke of a meeting held on 8 May at West Epping Bowling Club when a number of people involved in the production of the program Jack High were present. It was therefore with some regret that I had the opportunity of reading this week a statement by Mr David Hill dated 13 November. That statement said:

The managing director of the ABC, Mr David Hill, said today the corporation would continue to televise lawn bowls in 1988. However, it is unlikely to be associated with the Mazda company, which has been the sponsor of the series Jack High.
The statement went on:
Given budget problems it was decided recently that the ABC would not cover the next Jack High tournament, to be played in Sydney.
Mr Hill said this decision had caused misunderstanding, with many lawn bowlers believing that the ABC had withdrawn completely from the coverage of the game.
He said another problem with Jack High had been the excessive advertising displayed by Mazda around the venue.

I must say that I was somewhat surprised by that statement, coming so late in the day as it did. One would have thought that the way in which the Mazda company was associated with this production would have been raised as a question at the meeting at West Epping on 8 May. One would have thought that if it were a real problem, which should have been addressed before any suspension of the program was undertaken, some discussions would have been elicited with Mazda and the bowls fraternity about the future of the game. I implore the ABC, as I have before, to review the decision that it has taken in this matter, to ensure that Jack High is broadcast during the bicentennial year and that the program promised and the commitments given be honoured.

But few of us would doubt that the only reason for John Elliott's acceptance of the presidence of the Australian-Soviet Friendship Society was the fact that his commercial organisation is the largest commercial dealer with the Soviet Union and the Soviet Union had put pressure on him to accept that position. Those honourable members who followed the royal commission which was set up after the David Combe affair would be aware of the sort of pressure which is exerted by the Soviet Union on those who wish to trade with it. Those honourable members who are interested in the general problem of the association of Soviet commercial interests and its interference in other countries' politics should look at the official list of donations to Japanese political parties, which is published each year. TALK.START.PARA: —In the adjournment debate tonight, I have been furnished with the opportunity to present to the House an area of widespread concern and frustration, highlighted by a constituent of mine, Mr Victor de Verteuil from Toowoomba. Mr de Verteuil has articulated the feelings shared by many people who live outside the metropolitan area, thereby being forced to rely for their television viewing upon regional country networks which provide a very good service, yet which are obviously not in a financial position to purchase televising rights, and therefore rely on arrangements from relevant networks. These people represent almost one-third of the total Australian television viewers, including, of course, those residing in the metropolitan areas. Mr de Verteuil's concern, quite justifiably, focuses primarily on the situation whereby television networks seek to buy the sole rights to televise particular international sporting events, yet choose merely to show edited highlights of these events, if indeed anything at all.

SPEECH.PARA: In section 83, sub-section (5) of the Broadcasting Act of 1942, it is stipulated that an application for the grant of a licence shall, before the licence is granted, give an undertaking in writing to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, that the network will, if the licence is granted to it, comply with the conditions of the licence. Mr de Verteuil believes, as do I, that if a network seeks to purchase the sole rights to a sporting event, it should be obliged to cover the entire event. Its current tactic of withholding coverage of certain events, means that it is effectively holding the viewing public to ransom.

Let me cite but two examples of this. First of all, I wish to refer to the exciting final of the Davis Cup played on 4 October. Tennis fans had been afforded the opportunity to follow the progress of the tournament through preliminary matches. However, they were denied the opportunity to watch the most important match of the tournament when it was dropped in favour of televising the James Hardie 1000 motor race from Bathurst. A more recent example is the case of Channel 9 buying the exclusive rights to televise the World Cup cricket, yet merely choosing to show a live telecast of the first half of the final, thus depriving no fewer than 1.5 million cricket followers the opportunity of being witness to their long-awaited win. So Australia makes cricketing history, unwitnessed by Australian fans, yet televised in countries neither as affluent as Australia nor even participating in the event. This is strange for a country such as Australia which is so demonstrably proud of the achievements of its sports men and women.

In view of the fact that in Australia there are currently three major commercial television networks, as well as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, such clashes should be unheard and are clearly unacceptable. The public good is not only served but also seen to be served when people are given access by right, and not by the whim of a monopoly, to witness sporting events in which their country is a participant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During a previous adjournment debate I spoke about the proposed changes that are being flagged with respect to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. I was talking about the Workcare system in Victoria. Claims that Workcare would be an incentive for injured workers to return to the work force and that that would abolish the rorts flowing from awards of lump sum compensation have been proved to be no more than flash hopes based on an ideology which has no foundation. Partially incapacitated workers in Victoria are now spending an average of 26 weeks on compensation. Under the old common law scheme the average was 17 days. Injured workers are not returning to the work force. They are becoming long term dependants on the scheme instead.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the advisory body to the Commonwealth Government is putting forward those very same arguments to justify its proposal to amend the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. These arguments, like those used by the Victorian Government in 1985, have no basis in fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I do not need the help of the honourable member for Gippsland. Let us look at the claim that the common law is the reason why injured workers are not returning to the work force. This argument is ridiculous in light of statistics published in the annual report of the Commission for Employees Compensation 1984-85. During that 12-month period, there were 39,420 injuries in respect of which determinations under the Act were made, and 19,804 injuries in respect of which determinations under the Act were made before 1 July 1984 and for which payments were made during 1984-85. During that year, 196 employees were interviewed by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service for rehabilitation assistance. Out of these new referrals and a carry-over from the previous year, only 150 were accepted, 34 were rejected, four were deferred and eight cases remained undetermined at the close of the financial year. During 1984-85 only 90 employees completed rehabilitation programs. Following rehabilitation, 26 employees returned to employment during the year.

SPEECH.PARA: In the annual report of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation 1985-86, statistics show that during this period there were 29,211 injuries in respect of which determinations under the Act were made. There were also 28,337 injuries in respect of which determinations under the Act were made before 1 July 1985 for which payments were made during 1985-86. During that year, 347 employees were interviewed by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service for rehabilitation assistance. Out of these new referrals and a carry-over from the previous year, 310 were accepted, 33 were rejected and four were deferred. During 1985-86, 299 employees completed rehabilitation programs following rehabilitation and 74 employees returned to work during the year.

Let me now turn to the claim that the present system costs too much to run and that the abolition of common law rights will substantially reduce those costs. Despite extravagant claims in the Press that the proposed new scheme will, by abolishing common law rights, effect a cost saving of $1 billion, I understand that the amount paid by the Commonwealth Government to employees as a result of successful common law actions is extremely small compared with the overall cost of the workers compensation scheme. There is no specific information relating to the amounts paid and, more importantly, to the components of such payments. While there is no evidence available to support the argument that the abolition of common law rights will effect any cost reductions, there are clear indications that it will produce significant cost increases. The current proposal aims to abolish common law actions for economic loss and non-economic loss. I do not believe any case has been made out for the need to abolish the hard won common law rights in the course of a review of Commonwealth government workers compensation legislation. I hope and expect that those who speak for the workers whose rights will be lost by these proposals will make their voices heard in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is to be hoped that the people of Latvia, in the course of their current struggle to throw off the yoke of their Soviet rulers, are aware that news of their continuing struggle has reached Australia. It is also to be hoped that they are aware that many parts of the Western Press have reported most recently the demonstrations that took place in Riga, the capital of Latvia. On that date a number of Latvians on their national day decided to embark upon what the Soviet authorities obviously regarded as a heinous crime. The crime that they proposed to commit-for crime undoubtedly the Soviet authorities would regard it as-was to lay flowers at the freedom monument in Riga.

SPEECH.PARA: The response of the Soviet authorities to this activity, despite Mr Gorbachev's protestations of glasnost-a new openness and a new freedom, as they call it-was to prevent those Latvians from expressing in their own way the significance to them of their national day on 18 November. The Soviet police, numbering some 700 to 1,000, and a civilian vigilante force of 3,000 prevented those citizens of Latvia from expressing their sentiments on their national day and tried to prevent them in this most outrageous way from expressing their feeling that they still, as they undoubtedly are, are citizens of an entirely independent country.

We saw on this occasion one more piece of evidence of the continuing attempt by the Soviet Union to enforce its shackles on some of the millions of people who live under that oppressive regime. The Soviet authorities, driven to defend themselves, wheeled out what they no doubt regarded as an articulate and persuasive advocate to speak for their cause. Whom did they wheel out to present their case but Mr Kim Philby. The people of Latvia should be told, as I hope they will be, if news of what I am saying ever reaches them-and I hope it does-that Kim Philby was a traitor. Irrespective of the rights or wrongs of the matter, he was a traitor, a person who sold out his own country to an alien ideology for money and for the rewards that the Soviet Union offered him and has continued to offer him since he defected. He was the scurrilous individual on whom the Soviet Union had to rely to present its case and to argue in public in Latvia to try to dissuade Latvians from demonstrating and expressing their desire that they might one day again be free.

Here we have in a nutshell a very good example of exactly the way in which the Soviet Union in reality rules what is undoubtedly its own empire. This is the way it rules: by Soviet policemen preventing people from demonstrating peacefully. It uses the Soviet army and the Soviet police to do so and people who get in their way are simply trampled upon and pushed out of the way to prevent them from expressing their hopes of freedom. Then, with the most insulting argument of all, the Soviets bring out someone like Kim Philby to advance their case.

I hope that the people of Latvia will know that there are people in the West who are still advocating their cause; that there are people in the West who hope that the Latvians will one day be free; that there are people such as those on this side of the House, if not those on the other side of the House, who remember that the Latvians are now under the yoke of the Soviet Union and who would encourage them to continue their fight to regain the independence of their country and their freedoms and liberties which the Soviet Union presently denies them.
