TALK.START.PARA: —The award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Costa Rica's President Oscar Arias Sanchez was not only a great personal triumph but also an appropriate recognition of a plan which could mean `the possible return of peace and stability to a region long torn by strife and civil war'. That quotation is from the Nobel Peace Prize Committee. It is now over two months since the peace plan was signed by the Presidents of the Central American countries of Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and Nicaragua. But, despite strong support for the plan by the Nicaraguan Government and the El Salvador guerrillas, the United States Government has refused to welcome and support the plan, even though a number of members of Congress support it. On the contrary, President Reagan, against the wishes of many members of the United States Congress, is continuing to seek funding in support of the murderous attacks on civilians by the Contra forces in the country areas of Nicaragua.
—It is outrageous.

—It is outrageous, as the honourable member for Throsby comments. To continue with my speech, noting that the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown) is in the chamber, I want to make some comments about an adjournment speech by the honourable member on Wednesday, 4 November, and indeed about interjections made by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) during my speech on Tuesday, 3 November, on the abuse of human rights in Chile. I agree with the honourable member for Menzies that there are abuses of human rights in countries with left wing governments. Regrettably, abuses of human rights occur in counties of all political persuasions. There are also abuses of human rights in the United States of America, in Northern Ireland--
—And in Queensland.

—Yes, there are abuses of human rights in Queensland, in Australia, and, of course, in Tibet and Afghanistan. The problem with members of the Opposition is that they fail to realise that the abuses of human rights which I speak about in this House are so widespread and so brutal that reports of those abuses are appearing in the media virtually every day. Finally, let me point out to the honourable member for Menzies that in my speech I did not support the breaking of diplomatic relations with Chile but was in fact quoting the terms of the petition to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which had been presented by the Chilean protest group. In fact, I am pleased to report to the House that the group has ceased its protest hunger strike because of the sympathetic response it received from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) and from members on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: I want just to return to the main topic of my speech, which is President Arias's central American peace plan and the award of the Nobel Peace Prize. The peace plan had already achieved results in El Salvador and Nicaragua, with President Duarte of El Salvador calling on the Reagan Administration to give the peace process a fair chance by withholding military aid to the Nicaraguan Contras until at least January. Both in El Salvador and Nicaragua efforts are being made to meet the terms of the peace plan. In El Salvador talks were to be held between the Government and the Farabundo Marti de Liberacion Nacional and Frente Democratico Revolucionario left wing guerrillas. In Nicaragua the Government had declared a ceasefire in the four war zones where its military forces had been fighting the right wing counter-revolutionaries. The Government had also lifted censorship on the Opposition's newspaper La Prensa and the radio station of the Catholic Church.

Since the commencement of the implementation of the peace plan, however, right wing groups in El Salvador and Nicaragua have set about sabotaging the plan. In El Salvador, Mr Herbert Ernesto Anaya, President of the non-governmental Human Rights Commission of El Salvador, was murdered by a right wing death squad. In our Parliament, 12 members of the Federal parliamentary group Parliamentarians for Democracy in Latin America were so outraged by the death of the highly respected human rights campaigner that we sent a telegram to President Duarte in which we asked what was being doing to apprehend the criminals responsible, to protect activists in other human rights organisations from a similar fate, and to eliminate the death squads.

In Nicaragua, the Contra rebels have shunned the offers of an amnesty by the Nicaraguan Government, which was the condition for peace talks with that Government. Peace commissions were set up in all war zones but the Contra military leaders have warned their men that they will be killed if they leave the rebel forces and take amnesty. The guerrilla wars in both Nicaragua and El Salvador have resulted in extreme economic and social hardships for the people, and yet the right wing forces in both countries are determined to sabotage the peace plan with their murderous activities. President Arias of Costa Rica is to be congratulated on his peace plan and the winning of the Nobel Peace Prize and I will make no excuse for bringing such an important initiative to the attention of this House. My only hope is that the Nicaraguan and El Salvador governments will continue to work for the peace plan and that the United States Congress will urge President Reagan to cease his support and encouragement of the Contra counter revolutionaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the night of 21 June 1966, during the Federal election campaign of that year, the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, Arthur Calwell, addressed a lively gathering at the Mosman Town Hall. While he spoke a 19-year-old male stood listening in the lobby of the hall, but left before the meeting finished to go to the gardens of the nearby Methodist church to recover an object he had planted there.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the meeting Arthur Calwell emerged from the hall and proceeded to his Commonwealth car, which he entered and sat in the front seat on the passenger side. The door was closed for him. Calwell had a habit of always travelling with his car window open. But having just entered the car, fortunately the window was still closed. I say fortunately because less than six feet away from Mr Calwell was this 19-year-old with a sawn-off .22 rifle.

He fired a shot at Mr Calwell but the window took the brunt of the shot which some said would otherwise almost certainly have killed him. Calwell felt a stinging sensation in the front of his face and chin, and had a blood-splattered lower face. However, he was relatively unharmed and, typical of the man, was only concerned with ringing his wife, Elizabeth, in Melbourne to tell her he was okay. He was discharged from hospital the following evening.

The would-be assassin was born on 4 May 1947 in Newcastle, and christened Peter Raymond Douglas. However his father, an engineer, was killed in a car accident before his son was born. Five years later Peter Douglas's mother remarried Ludovit Kocan and the family lived in Melbourne. The marriage later broke up but the son assumed and retained the name Peter Kocan. After working in the country as a labourer and station hand he eventually moved to Sydney. He once wrote to the Sydney Headquarters of the Nazi Party that he admired Hitler because he had killed himself at the right time.
He wanted notoriety of the kind received by Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of John F. Kennedy. He was quoted as saying:
I had to do something to set me aside from all the other nobodies.

The defence psychiatrist who examined Peter Kocan described him as `a borderline schizophrenic'. Because Kocan disagreed with Calwell's political views he was sufficiently unbalanced to want to assassinate him. Kocan pleaded guilty. He was sentenced to life imprisonment for his murder attempt, and on 30 December 1966 transferred from Long Bay Gaol to the Morisset asylum for the criminally insane. There he remained until his release 10 years later on a five-year licence. While at the Morisset mental asylum he became interested in writing poetry and novels.

One of his composite books The Treatment and the Cure was recommended reading in New South Wales for Higher School Certificate students in 1986. I was disappointed to see a number of schools take up the recommendation because I believe the author's past history of attempted assassination alone should have automatically precluded him from having his book considered for school children. There were those who argued that the book had literary merit. This claim, of course, is nonsense. The book is riddled with some the most pornographic, vile and sick language I have ever seen. There are pages laced with vivid descriptions of deranged people, of masturbation, of homosexual behaviour, of deviants ejaculating into the cups of women's bras for their thrills, and so on. The language used throughout the book could hardly be cruder and goes well beyond the bounds of decency. If people want to write this sort of stuff, so be it. However, by no stretch of the imagination should this be forced on school children. I had some parents complain to me it was unduly distressing for their children.

I am also enraged to discover that this ex-would-be assassin has also been singled out for extravagant favouritism by the Australia Council. In the five grants he has received he has been lavished with taxpayers' money. In 1977, 1980 and 1982 he received grants for $10,000, $15,000 and $9,375 respectively. But only recently the amounts of money have markedly increased. In 1984 Kocan was given $25,000 for yet another senior fellowship. Now, only 3 weeks ago, another $29,000 of taxpayers' money was given to Kocan so that he can write poetry for a year. That is a total of $88,375.

I do not begrudge this man any success he may have had at rehabilitating himself. However, I resent the influence he is having on our children, and the way he is draining our taxpayers' funds. When delightful books like Enid Blyton's Noddy books are banned from school libraries and weirdo rubbish like Kocan's is replacing them, and at taxpayers' expense, I sometimes wonder at the direction in which this country is headed.
